sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: On the contrary , I 'm in the very best of health .

lg.l: But I saw in the papers that you were going to give up your seat in the
House owing to ill-health .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Of course , I 'd forgotten . My heart is seriously deranged .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: How dreadful ! What is the matter with it ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Can you ask ? I 've banged it about at your feet so long that its functions are excessively impaired . And it 's beaten all my waistcoats out of shape .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Do n't be so foolish . I was quite alarmed .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I 'm going to retire .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: From the bar as well ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: From the bar as well . Henceforth I shall cultivate only such arts and graces as are proper to the man of leisure . My fellow men are a great deal too strenuous , and I propose to offer them the spectacle of a complete idler who demands from the world neither honours nor profit , but only entertainment .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: D'you mean to say you 're going to give up a large practice and a position which may be very important merely to gratify a foolish whim ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I have n't time to work . Life is so much too short . A little while ago it occurred to me that I was nearly forty .To MRS. CROWLEY .D'you know the feeling ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: No , of course not . Do n't be so uncivil .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: By the way , how old are you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Twenty-nine !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Nonsense ! There 's no such age .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I beg your pardon , upper parlourmaids are always twenty-nine .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: For years I 've spent eight hours a day meddling with silly persons ’ silly quarrels , and eight hours more governing the nation . I 've never been able to spend more than half my income . I 'm merely working myself to death in order to leave a fortune to my nieces , two desperately plain girls with red noses .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: But what are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know . Perhaps I 'll try my hand at big game shooting , if Alec will take me on this expedition of his . I 've always thought shooting would be an agreeable pastime if partridges were the size of well-grown sheep and pheasants a little larger than a cow .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Then the breakdown in your health is all humbug ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Absolute humbug . If I were to tell the truth people would shut me up in a lunatic asylum . I 've come to the conclusion that there 's only one game in the world worth playing , and that 's the game of life . I 'm rich enough to devote myself to it entirely .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: But you 'll get bored to death .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Not I ! Why , I 'm growing younger every day . My dear Mrs. Crowley , I do n't feel a day more than eighteen .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You certainly look quite twenty-five .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I have n't a white hair in my head .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I suppose your servant plucks them out every morning .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , very rarely . One a month at the outside .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I think I see one on the left temple .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Really ! How careless of Charles ! I must speak to him .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Let me pluck it out .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I shall allow you to do nothing so familiar .

div.stage: GEORGE comes hurriedly into the room .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There 's Alec Mackenzie . He 's just driven up in a cab .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: He must have come from the trial . Then it 's all over .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Quick ! Go to the stairs , or Miller wo n't let him up .

div.stage: GEORGE runs across the room and opens the door .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Calling .Miller , Miller , Mr. Mackenzie 's to come up .

div.stage: LUCY ALLERTON , hearing a commotion , comes in . She is older than George , a tall girl , white now , with eyes heavy from want of sleep . She has lived in the country all her life , and has brought up to London a sort of remoteness from the world . She is beautiful in a very English manner , and her clear-cut features are an index to a character in which the moral notions are peculiarly rigid . Self-control is a quality which she possesses in a marked degree , and one which she enormously admires in others .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Who is it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's Alec Mackenzie . He 's come from the trial !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Then it 's finished at last .She shakes hands with DICK .It 's so good of you to come .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: You 're perfectly wonderful , Lucy . How can you be so calm ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Because I 'm quite sure of the result . D'you imagine I 'd doubt my father for a moment ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , Lucy , for heaven 's sake do n't be so sure . You must be prepared for everything .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , no , I know my father . D'you think I 've not studied him during these years that I 've looked after him ? He 's a child , with all a child 's thoughtlessness and simplicity . And God knows , he 's weak . I know his faults better than any one , but it would be impossible for him to do anything criminal .

div.stage: The BUTLER enters , followed by ALEC MACKENZIE . ALEC is a tall , wiry man , well-knit , with dark hair and a small red moustache and beard , cut close to the face . He is about five-and-thirty . He has great ease of manner , and there is about him an air as though he were accustomed that people should do as he told them .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Mr. Mackenzie !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Is it finished ? For God 's sake tell us quickly , old man .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Why did n't father come with you ? Is he following ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Yes , it 's all over .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Thank goodness . The suspense was really too dreadful .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I knew they 'd acquit him . Thank God !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Looking at ALEC 'S face .Take care , George .

div.stage: Suddenly LUCY goes up to ALEC and looks at him . An expression of horror distorts her features .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Lucy , what is it ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I do n't know how I am going to tell you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You say the trial was over when you came away ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: The jury had given their verdict ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Lucy , what are you driving at ? You do n't think ...?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Your father asked me to come and break it to you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 's not dead ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Perhaps it would be better if he were .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: They found him guilty ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a groan of despair .Oh ! But it 's impossible .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Putting her hand on his arm .Ssh !

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: My God , my God ! I 'm thankful that his wife is dead .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I 'm awfully stupid , but if he was innocent , how could they find him guilty ? I do n't know what you mean .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I am afraid it 's very clear .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: There must be some horrible mistake .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I wish there were .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Breaking down into tears and sinking into a chair .Oh , God ! What shall I do ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Do n't do that , George . We want all our calmness now .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do n't you see they all expected it ? It was only you and I who believed in his innocence .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: To ALEC .Did you hear the evidence ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And you followed it carefully ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Very .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: What impression did it leave on your mind ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: What can it matter how it affected me ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I want to know .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Lucy , you 're torturing us all .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: If you had been on the jury would your verdict have been the same as theirs ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I should have been obliged to judge according to my conscience .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I see . And you have no doubt that he was guilty ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do n't ask me these horrible questions .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But it 's very important . I know that you are a perfectly honest and upright man . If you think he was guilty , there is nothing more to be said .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: The case was so plain that the jury were not out of the box for more than ten minutes .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Did the judge say anything ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Hesitatingly .He said there could be no doubt about the justice of the verdict .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: What else ?...He looks at her without answering .You had better tell me now . I shall see it in the papers to-morrow .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: As though the words were dragged out of him .He called it a very mean and shameful crime , worse than another man 's because your father was a gentleman of ancient family and bore a name of great honour .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: To MRS. CROWLEY .These judges have a weakness for pointing a moral .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And what was the sentence ?A pause .Well ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Seven years ’ penal servitude .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , God !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My dear girl , I can n't tell you how sorry I am .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Lucy , what is it ? You frighten me .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Try and bear up , George . We want all the strength we 've got , you and I .

div.stage: MRS. CROWLEY puts her arms round LUCY and kisses her .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Oh , my dear , my dear !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Disengaging herself .You 're all very kind , and I know you sympathise with me ....

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Interrupting her .You know that we 'll do everything we can to help you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: It 's so good of you . There 's really nothing that any one can do . Would you all mind leaving me alone with George ? We must talk this over by ourselves .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Very well . Mr. Lomas , will you put me into a cab ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Certainly .To LUCY .Good-bye , dear , and God bless you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Shaking hands with him .Do n't worry too much about me . If there 's anything I want , I 'll let you know .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Thanks .

div.stage: He goes out with MRS. CROWLEY .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: May I speak to you for a few minutes alone ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Not now , Mr. Mackenzie . I do n't want to seem rude , but ...

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Interrupting .I know , and I would n't insist unless it were a matter of the most urgent importance .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Very well . George , will you take Aunt Alice to her room ? I shall want you in a moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: To LADY KELSEY .Wo n't you lie down and try and sleep a little ? You must be dreadfully exhausted .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Ah , do n't think of me now , dear . Think of yourself .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Smiling .It 's purely selfish . It eases me a little to fuss about you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'll wait in the smoking-room , Lucy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Do !

div.stage: GEORGE and LADY KELSEY go out .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I think your self-command is wonderful . I 've never admired you more than at this moment .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You make me feel such a prig . It 's not really very strange if I keep my head , because I 've had an immensely long training . Since I was fifteen I 've been alone to care for George and my father .... Wo n't you sit down ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I can say what I want in a very few words . You know that in a week I start for Mombassa to take charge of the expedition in North-East Africa . I may be away for three or four years , and I shall be exposed to a certain amount of danger . When I left Africa last time to gather supplies , I determined I would crush those wretched slave-traders , and now I think I have the means to do it .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I think you are engaged on a very great work .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I do n't know whether you ever noticed that — that I cared more for you than for any one in the world . But with the long journey in front of me I did n't think it was right to say anything to you . It was n't fair to ask you to bind yourself during my long absence . And there was always the risk that a stray bullet might put an end to me . I made up my mind that I must wait till I returned . But things have changed now . Lucy , I love you with all my heart . Will you marry me before I go ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No , I can n't do that . It 's very generous of you , but I could n't .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Why not ? Do n't you know that I love you ? It would help me so much if I knew that you were waiting for me at home .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I must look after my father . I shall go and live near the — prison , so that I can see him whenever it 's possible .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You can do that as well if you 're my wife .... You have before you a very difficult and trying time . Wo n't you let me help you ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I could n't . Heaven knows , I 'm grateful to you for offering to marry me on this day of my bitter humiliation . I shall never forget your great kindness . But I must stand alone . I must devote myself to my father . When he 's released I must have a home to bring him to , and I must tend him and care for him . Ah , now he wants me more than ever .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You 're very proud .

lg.l: Dear friend , do n't think hardly of me . I think
I love you as much as it 's possible for a woman to love a man .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Lucy !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: With a smile .Did you want me to tell you that in so many words ? I admire you , and I trust you . I should be very happy if George could grow into so brave and honest a man as you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: They 're very modest crumbs with which you want me to be satisfied .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I know in your heart you think I 'm right . You would never seek to dissuade me from what I 'm convinced is my duty .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Ca n't I do anything for you at all ?

div.stage: She looks at him for a moment intently . She rings the bell .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes , you can do me the greatest possible service .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm so glad . What is it you mean ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Wait , and I 'll tell you .The BUTLER enters .Ask Mr. George to come here , please .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Very well , Miss .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I want you to help me .

div.stage: GEORGE comes in .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , Lucy ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I want to give into your charge what I love most in the world .... George , have you thought at all what you 're going to do now ? I 'm afraid you can n't go back to Oxford .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , I do n't know what 's to become of me . I wish I were dead .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: An idea has just come to me . I 'm going to ask Mr. Mackenzie to take you with him to Africa . Will you go ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes ! I 'd do anything to get away from England . I dare n't face my friends — I 'm too ashamed .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Ah , but it 's not to hide yourself that I want you to go . Mr. Mackenzie , I daresay you know that we 've always been very proud of our name . And now it 's hopelessly dishonoured .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Lucy , for God 's sake ...

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Turning to him .Now our only hope is in you . You have the opportunity of achieving a great thing . You can bring back the old name to its old honour . Oh , I wish I were a man . I can do nothing but wait and watch . If I could only fill you with my courage and with my ambition ! Mr. Mackenzie , you asked if you could do anything for me . You can give George the chance of wiping out the shame of our family .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do you know that he will have to suffer every sort of danger and privation , that often he will be parched by the heat , and often soaked to the skin for days together ? Sometimes he 'll not have enough to eat , and he 'll have to work harder than a navvy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Do you hear , George ? Are you willing to go ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'll do anything you want me to , Lucy .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: And you know that he may get killed . There may be a good deal of fighting .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: If he dies a brave man 's death , I have nothing more to ask .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: To GEORGE .Very well . Come with me , and I 'll do my best for you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Ah , thanks . You are really my friend .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: And when I come back ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Then , if you still care , ask your question again .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: And the answer ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: With a little smile .The answer , perhaps , will be different . END OF THE FIRST ACT

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: SCENE : ALEC MACKENZIE 'S tent in North-East Africa . It is night . The place is dimly lighted . There is a little camp bed in one corner with a mosquito net over it . There are two or three folding chairs , some tin cases , and a table . On this a gun is lying .

DICK is seated with his head on his hands , leaning on the table , fast asleep . DR. ADAMSON , the surgeon of the expedition , comes in . He is a large-boned brawny fellow with a Scotch accent . He looks at DICK and smiles .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Hulloa , there !DICK starts up and seizes the gun . The DOCTOR laughs .All right . Do n't shoot . It 's only me .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: With a laugh .Why the dickens did you wake me up ? I was dreaming — dreaming of a high-heeled boot and a neat ankle , and the swish of a white lace petticoat .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I thought I 'd just have a look at your arm .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's one of the most aesthetic sights I know .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Your arm ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: A pretty woman crossing Piccadilly at Swan and Edgar 's . You are a savage , my good doctor , and a barbarian . You do n't know the care and forethought , the hours of anxious meditation , it has needed for her to hold up that well-made skirt with the elegant grace which enchants you .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 're a very immoral man , Lomas .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Ah , my dear fellow , at my time of life I have to content myself with condemning the behaviour of the younger generation . Even a camp bed in a stuffy tent with mosquitoes buzzing all around me has allurements greater than those of youth and beauty . And I declare for all women to hear that I am proof against their wiles . Give me a comfortable bed to sleep in , plenty to eat , tobacco to smoke , and Amaryllis may go hang .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Well , let 's look at this wound of yours . Has it been throbbing at all ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , it 's not worth bothering about . It 'll be all right to-morrow .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I 'll put a clean dressing on all the same .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: All right .He takes off his coat and rolls up his sleeve . His arm is bandaged , and during the next speeches the DOCTOR puts on a dressing and a clean bandage .You must be pretty well done up , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Just about dropping . But I 've got a deuce of a lot more work before I turn in .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: The thing that amuses me is to remember that I came to Africa thinking I was going to have a rattling good time .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You could n't exactly describe it as a picnic , could you ? But I do n't suppose any of us knew it would be such a tough job as it 's turned out .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My friend , if ever I return to my native land , I will never be such a crass and blithering idiot as to give way again to a spirit of adventure .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: With a laugh .You 're not the sort of chap whom one would expect to take to African work . Why the blazes did you come ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: That 's precisely what I 've been asking myself ever since we landed in this God-forsaken swamp .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: The wound looks healthy enough . It 'll hardly even leave a scar .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I 'm glad that my fatal beauty wo n't be injured .... You see , Alec 's about the oldest friend I have . And then there 's young Allerton , I 've known him ever since he was a kid .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: That 's an acquaintance that most of us would n't boast about .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I had an idea I 'd like Bond Street all the better when I got back . I never knew that I should be eaten alive by every kind of disgusting animal by night and day . I say , Doctor , do you ever think of a rump steak ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: When ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: With a wave of the hand .Sometimes , when we 're marching under a sun that just about takes the roof of your head off , and we 've had the scantiest and most uncomfortable breakfast possible , I have a vision .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: D'you mind only gesticulating with one arm ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I see the dining-room of my club and myself sitting at a little table by the window looking out on Piccadilly , and there 's a spotless tablecloth , and all the accessories are spick and span . An obsequious servant brings me a rump steak , grilled to perfection , and so tender that it melts in the mouth . And he puts by my side a plate of crisp , fried potatoes . Ca n't you smell them ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Laughing .Shut up !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And then another obsequious servant brings me a pewter tankard , and into it he pours a bottle , a large bottle , mind you , of foaming ale .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You 've certainly added considerably to our cheerfulness .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .I 've often been driven to appease the pangs of raging hunger with a careless epigram , and by the laborious composition of a limerick I have sought to deceive a most unholy thirst .

lg.l: Well , last night I thought you 'd made your last joke , old man , and that
I had given my last dose of quinine .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: We were in rather a tight corner , were n't we ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: This is the third expedition I 've gone with Mackenzie against the slave-raiders , and I promise you I 've never been so certain that all was over with us .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Funny thing death is , you know . When you think of it beforehand , it makes you squirm in your shoes , but when you 've just got it face to face , it seems so obvious that you forget to be afraid . It 's one of my principles never to be impressed by a platitude .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: It 's only by a miracle we escaped . If those Arabs had n't hesitated to attack us just those ten minutes we should have been wiped out .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Alec was splendid , was n't he ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Yes , by Jove ! He thought we were done for .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Well , you see , I know him pretty well . He 's been a pal of yours for twenty years in England , but I 've been with him out here three times , and I tell you there 's not much about a man that you do n't know then .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Well , when things are going smoothly and everything 's flourishing , he 's apt to be a bit irritable . He keeps rather to himself , and he does n't say much unless you do something he does n't approve of .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And then , by Jove , he comes down on one like a thousand of bricks . It 's not for nothing the natives call him Thunder and Lightning .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: But when things begin to look black , his spirits go up like one o'clock . And the worse they are , the more cheerful he is .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's one of his most irritating characteristics .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: When every one is starving with hunger , and dead tired , and soaked to the skin , Mackenzie fairly bubbles over with good-humour .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: When I 'm in a bad temper , I much prefer every one else to be in a bad temper too .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: These last few days , he 's been positively hilarious . Yesterday he was cracking jokes with the natives .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Dryly .Scotch jokes . I daresay they sound funny in an African dialect .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I 've never seen him more cheerful . I said to myself : By the Lord Harry , the chief thinks we 're in a devil of a bad way .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Thank Heaven , it 's all over now . We 've none of us had any sleep for three days , and when I once get off , I do n't mean to wake up for a week .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I must go and see the rest of my patients . Perkins has got a bad dose of fever this time . He was quite delirious a while ago .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: By Jove , I 'd almost forgotten . How one changes out here ! Here am I feeling happy and comfortable and inclined to make a little jest or two , and I 've forgotten already that poor Richardson is dead and Lord knows how many natives .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Poor chap , we could ill spare him . The fates never choose the right man .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What do you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: If we had to lose some one , it would have been a damned sight better if that young cub had got the bullet which killed poor Richardson .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: George Allerton ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: He would n't have been much loss , would he ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No , I 'm afraid he would n't .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Mackenzie has been very patient with him . I wonder he did n't send him back to the coast months ago , when he sacked Macinnery .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Poor George , everything has been against him .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Some men have got natures so crooked that with every chance in the world to go straight they can n't manage it . The only thing is to let them go to the devil as best they may .

lg.l: Alec was bound to give him another chance .
Hulloa , Alec ! Where have you been ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 've been going the round of the outlying sentries .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: All serene ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Yes . I 've just seen a native messenger that Mindabi sent to me .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Anything important ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Curtly .Yes . How 's the arm , Dick ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , that 's nothing . It 's only a scratch .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You 'd better not make too light of it . The smallest wound has a way of being troublesome in this country .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: He 'll be all right in a day or two .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: How are the others ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: They 're going on pretty well on the whole . Perkins , of course , will be down for some days longer . And some of the natives are rather badly hurt . Those devils have got explosive bullets .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Any one in great danger ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: No , I do n't think so . There are two men who are in rather a bad way , but all they want is rest .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I say , have you had anything to eat lately ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a laugh .Good Lord ! I quite forgot . I wonder when the dickens I had some food last .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Smiling .You 've had nothing to-day , have you ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No , I do n't think so . Those Arabs kept us so confoundedly busy .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You must be devilish hungry .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Now you mention it , I think I am . And thirsty , by Jove ! I would n't give my thirst for an elephant tusk .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And to think there 's nothing but tepid water to drink !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I 'll go and tell the boy to bring you some food . It 's a rotten game to play tricks with your digestion like that .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Gaily .Stern man , the doctor , is n't he ? It wo n't hurt me once in a way . And I shall enjoy it all the more now .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Calling .Selim !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No , do n't trouble . The poor chap 's just turned in , dropping with sleep . I told him he might till I called him . I do n't want much , and I can easily get it myself .He goes to a case and takes out a tin of meat and some ship 's biscuits .It 's rather a nuisance that we 've not been able to get any game lately .

div.stage: He sets the food down before him , sits down , and begins to eat .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Ironically .Appetising , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Splendid !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You have all the instincts of the primeval savage , Alec . It enrages and disgusts me .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a laugh .Why ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You take food for the gross and bestial purpose of appeasing your hunger . You have no appreciation for the delicacies of eating as a fine art .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: The meat 's getting rather mouldy , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Damnable ! It 's been a source of great anxiety to me in England .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: What is he talking about now ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I was going on with the thread of my observations , which you interrupted with the entirely obvious remark that the tinned meat was getting mouldy .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I apologise profusely . Pray go on !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I was about to observe that even in England you will eat the most carefully ordered meal with an indifference which is an outrage to decency . Indeed , you pay less attention to it than here , because at all events you do notice that the meat is mouldy . But if any one gives you a good dinner , you notice nothing . I 've given him priceless port , Doctor , and he drank it as though it were cooking sherry .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I confess it is lamentable . But why is it a source of anxiety to you ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What on earth is to happen to him in his old age ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Explain yourself , my friend . Clearly but with as much brevity as possible .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: The pleasure of eating is the only pleasure that remains to the old . Love — what is love when you lose your figure , and your hair grows thin ? Knowledge — one can never know everything , and the desire passes with the fire of youth . Even ambition fails you in the end . But to those who have lived wisely and well , there remain three pleasures every day of their lives : their breakfast , their luncheon , and their dinner .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a laugh .I would n't worry about my old age if I were you , Dick .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Because I think it 's ten to one that we shall all be dead to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: What ?

div.stage: There is a slight pause while both men stare at him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Is this one of your little jokes , Alec ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You have often observed that I joke with difficulty .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: But what 's wrong now ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You 'll neither of you sleep in your beds to-night . Another sell for the mosquitoes , is n't it ? I propose to break up the camp and start marching as soon as the moon goes down .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I say , it 's a bit thick after a day like this . We 're all so done up that we sha n't be able to go a mile .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Nonsense , you will have had two hours ’ rest .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: But some of those fellows who are wounded can n't possibly be moved .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: They must !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I wo n't answer for their lives .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: We must take the risk . Our only chance is to make a bold dash for it , and we can n't leave the wounded here .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I suppose there 's going to be a deuce of a row ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Grimly .There is .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Your companions seldom have a chance to complain of the monotony of their existence , Alec . What are you going to do now ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: At this moment , I 'm going to fill my pipe .

div.stage: There is a pause while ALEC fills and lights his pipe .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I gather from the general amiability of your demeanour that we 're in a rather tight place ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Tighter than any of your patent-leather boots , my friend .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Gravely .Have we any chance of getting through , old man ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Lightly .Oh , I do n't know . There 's always a chance .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Do n't grin at me in that irritating fashion .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You must wish you were treading the light fantastic toe in a London ball-room , Dick .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Frankly I do .... I suppose we 're going to fight again ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Like Kilkenny cats .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Briskly .Well , at all events that 's some comfort . If I am going to be done out of my night 's rest , I should like to take it out of some one .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: If things turn out all right , we shall have come near finishing the job , and there wo n't be much more slave-raiding in this part of Africa .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And if things do n't turn out all right ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Why , then I 'm afraid the tea-tables of Mayfair will be deprived of your scintillating repartee forever .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Well , I 've had a very good time in my life . I 've loved a little , I 've looked at some good pictures , read some thundering fine books , and I 've worked and played . If I can only account for a few more of those damned scoundrels before I die , I should n't think I had much to complain of .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Smiling .You 're a philosopher , Dick .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Does n't the possibility of an extremely unpleasant demise tempt you to a few appropriate reflections ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I do n't know that it does . I 'm a bit of a fatalist , and my theory is that when my time comes nothing can help me , but at the bottom of my heart I can n't resist the conviction that I sha n't die till I let myself .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Well , I must go and put things in order . I 'll bandage those fellows up , and I hope they 'll stand the jolting .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: What about Perkins ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Lord knows ! I 'll try and keep him quiet with chloral .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You need n't say anything about striking camp . I do n't propose that any one should know till a quarter of an hour before we start .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: But that wo n't give them time .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It must . I 've trained them often enough to get on the march quickly .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Very well .

div.stage: GEORGE ALLERTON comes in as the DOCTOR is on the point of going .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Can I come in ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Yes ... Doctor !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Hulloa !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You might stay a minute , will you ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Coming back .Certainly .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Did n't Selim tell you that I wanted to speak to you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's why I 've come .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You 've taken your time about it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I say , could you give me a drink of brandy ? I 'm awfully done up .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Shortly .There 's no brandy left .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Has n't the doctor got some ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No !

div.stage: There is a pause . ALEC looks at him slowly .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Why are you all looking at me like that ? You look as if you were going to try me for something .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Nonsense ! Do n't be so nervous .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Abruptly .Do you know anything about the death of that Turkana woman ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No ! How should I ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Come now , you must know something about it . Last Tuesday you came into camp and told me the Turkana were very excited .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Unwillingly .Oh , yes ! I remember something about it . It had slipped my memory .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm not very clear about it . The woman had been shot , had n't she ? One of our station boys had been playing the fool with her , and he seems to have shot her .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Have you made no inquiries as to who the man was ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: In a surly way .I have n't had time . We 've all been worked off our legs during these three days .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do you suspect no one ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Think a moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: The only man who might have done it is that big scoundrel whom we got on the coast , the Swahili .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 's been making an awful nuisance of himself , and I know he was running after her .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I understand she complained about him to you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do you think that would be enough evidence to punish him on ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 's a thorough blackguard , and after all , if one does make a mistake , he 's only a nigger .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You 'll be surprised to hear that when the woman was found she was n't dead .

div.stage: GEORGE gives a movement of consternation .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: She did n't die for nearly an hour .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: After a short pause .Was she able to say anything ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: She accused you of having shot her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It appears that you were playing the fool with her , and when she got angry you took out a revolver and fired point blank . Presumably that she should tell no tales .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's a stupid lie . You know what they are . It 's just like them to tell an absurd lie like that . You would n't believe a parcel of niggers rather than me , would you ? After all , my word 's worth more than theirs .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Taking from his pocket an exploded cartridge .This was found about two yards from the body . As you see , it 's a revolver cartridge . It was brought to me this evening .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't know what that proves .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You know just as well as I do that none of our natives has a revolver . Besides ourselves only two or three of the servants have them .

div.stage: GEORGE becomes white with fear , he takes out his handkerchief and wipes his face .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Quietly .Will you give me your revolver ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I have n't got it . I lost it in the skirmish this afternoon . I did n't tell you as I thought you 'd be annoyed .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I saw you cleaning it less than an hour ago .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .Perhaps it 's in my tent , I 'll go and see .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Sharply .Stop here .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Angrily .You 've no right to talk to me like that . I 'm sick to death of being ordered about . You seem to think I 'm a dog . I came out here of my own free will , and I wo n't let you treat me as if I were a servant .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: If you put your hand to your hip pocket , I think you 'll find your revolver there .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm not going to give it to you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Quietly .D'you want me to come and take it from you myself ?

div.stage: The two men stare at one another for a moment . Then GEORGE slowly puts his hand to his pocket . He lakes out the revolver and suddenly aims at ALEC . DICK beats up his arm as he fires , and the DOCTOR , springing forward , seizes him round the waist . ALEC remains still .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: During the struggle .You young blackguard !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Let me go , damn you !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You need not hold him .

div.stage: They leave go of GEORGE , who sinks cowering into a chair . DICK hands the revolver to ALEC . He silently fits into a chamber the cartridge that had been brought to him .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You see that it fits . Had n't you better make a clean breast of it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Cowed .Yes , I shot her . She made a row , and the devil got into me . I did n't know I 'd done anything till she screamed and I saw the blood .... What a fool I was to throw the cartridge away ! I wanted to have all the chambers charged .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do you remember that two months ago I hanged a man to the nearest tree because he 'd outraged a native woman ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Springing up in terror .You would n't do that to me , Alec . Oh , God , no , Alec , have mercy on me . You would n't hang me . Oh , why did I ever come to this damned place ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You need not be afraid . I 'm not going to do that . In any case I must preserve the native respect for the white man .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I was half drunk when I saw that woman . I was n't responsible for my actions .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: The result is that the whole tribe has turned against us . The chief is my friend , and he sent a message to tell me he could n't hold them in . It 's from him I got the cartridge . It would n't be so serious , only the best fighting part of our forces are the Turkana , and we must expect treachery . They 've stirred up the neighbouring tribes against us , and all the work we 've been doing for a year is undone . That 's the explanation of the Arabs ’ attack three days ago .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Sullenly .I knew it was all my fault .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: The natives have made up their minds to join the slave-traders , and we shall be attacked on all sides to-morrow . We can n't hold out against God knows how many thousands .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: D'you mean you 'll all be killed ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: If we remain here there 's no escape .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: In a whisper .What are you going to do to me , Alec ?

div.stage: ALEC walks up and down the tent .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Presently .I think you might go and see your patients now , doctor .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Shall I go too , Alec ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No , you can stay here . But do n't open your mouth till you 're spoken to .

div.stage: THE DOCTOR goes out .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm sorry I did that silly thing just now . I 'm glad I did n't hit you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It does n't matter at all . I 'd forgotten all about it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I lost my head , I did n't know what I was doing .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You need not trouble about that . In Africa even the strongest people are apt to get excited and lose their balance .

div.stage: ALEC re-lights his pipe , and there its a very short pause .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Did you ever know that before we came away I asked Lucy to marry me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I knew you cared for her .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: She asked me to bring you here in the hope that you would regain the good name of your family . I think that is the object she has most at heart in the world . It 's as great as her love for you . The plan has n't been much of a success , has it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: She ought to have known that I was n't suited for this kind of life .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I saw very soon that you were weak and irresolute . But I hoped to make something of you . Your intentions seemed good enough , but you never had the strength to carry them out .... I 'm sorry if I seem to be preaching to you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Bitterly .Oh , d'you think I care what any one says to me now ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Gravely , but not unkindly .Then I found you were drinking . I told you that no man could stand liquor in this country , and you gave me your word of honour that you would n't touch it again .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , I broke it . I could n't help it ; the temptation was too strong .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: When we came to the station at Muneas you and Macinnery got blind drunk , and the whole camp saw you . I ought to have sent you back to the coast then , but it would have broken Lucy 's heart .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It was Macinnery 's fault .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It 's because I thought he was to blame that I sent him back alone . I wanted to give you another chance . It struck me that the feeling of authority might have some influence on you , and so when we came to the lake I left you to guard the ferry . I put the chief part of the stores in your care and marched on . I need n't remind you what happened then .

div.stage: GEORGE looks down sulkily , and in default of excuses keeps silent .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I came to the conclusion that it was hopeless . You seemed to me rotten through and through .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a little laugh .Like my father before me .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I could n't believe a word you said . You did everything you should n't have done . The result was that the men mutinied , and if I had n't come back in the nick of time they 'd have killed you and looted all the stores .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You always blame me for everything . A man 's not responsible for what he does when he 's down with fever .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It was too late to send you back to the coast then , and I was obliged to take you on . And now the end has come . Your murder of that woman has put us all in deadly peril . Already to your charge lie the deaths of Richardson and almost twenty natives . Tribes that were friendly have joined with the Arabs , and we 're as near destruction as we can possibly be .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: We 're far away from the coast , and I must take the law into my own hands .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a gasp .You 're not going to kill me ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Are you fond of Lucy ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Brokenly .You — you know I am . Why d'you remind me of her now ? I 've made a rotten mess of everything , and I 'm better out of the way . But think of the disgrace of it . It 'll kill Lucy .... And she was hoping I 'd do so much .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Listen to me . Our only chance of escaping from the confounded fix we 're in is to make a sudden attack on the Arabs before the natives join them . We shall be enormously outnumbered , but we may just smash them if we can strike to-night . My plan is to start marching as if I did n't know that the Turkana were going to turn against us . After an hour all the whites but one , and the Swahilis whom I can trust implicitly , will take a short cut . The Arabs will have had news of our starting , and they 'll try to cut us off at the pass . I shall fall on them just as they begin to attack . D'you understand ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Now I must have one white man to head the Turkana , and that man will run the greatest possible danger . I 'd go myself , only the Swahilis wo n't fight unless I lead them .... Are you willing to take that post ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I could order you , but the job 's too dangerous for me to force it on any one . If you refuse , I shall call the others together and ask some one to volunteer . In that case you will have to find your way back alone as best you can to the coast .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , no ! Anything rather than the shame of that .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I wo n't hide from you that it means almost certain death . But there 's no other way of saving ourselves . On the other hand , if you show perfect courage at the moment the Arabs attack and the Turkana find that we 've given them the slip , you may escape . If you do , I promise nothing shall be said of all that has happened here .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: All right . I 'll do that . And I thank you with all my heart for giving me the chance .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm glad you 've accepted . Whatever happens you 'll have done a brave action in your life .He holds out his hand to GEORGE , who takes it .I think there 's nothing more to be said . You must be ready to start in half an hour . Here 's your revolver . Remember that one chamber 's empty . You 'd better put in another cartridge .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , I 'll do that .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: D'you think he has any chance of escaping ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: If he has pluck he may get through .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Well !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: To-morrow we shall know if he has that last virtue of a blackguard — courage .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And if he has n't , it 's death you 're sending him to ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Yes . It 's death ! END OF THE SECOND ACT

sp.speaker: THE THIRD ACT
sp.p: SCENE : A smoking-room at LADY KELSEY 'S , leading by an archway into a drawing-room at the back . On the right is a glass door which leads into the garden . On one side is a sofa ; on the other a table with cigarettes , matches , whiskey , sodas , etc . LADY KELSEY is giving a dance , and the music of the Lancers is heard vaguely from the ball-room as the curtain rises . MRS. CROWLEY and SIR ROBERT BOULGER are sitting down . LADY KELSEY comes in with the REV . JAMES CARBERY .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Oh , you wretched people , why are n't you dancing ? It 's too bad of you to hide yourselves here !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: We thought no one would find us in the smoking-room . But why have you abandoned your guests , Lady Kelsey ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Oh , I 've got them all comfortably settled in the Lancers , and I 'm free to rest myself for a quarter of an hour . You do n't know what agonies I 've been suffering the whole evening .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Good gracious me ! Why ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I 'm so afraid Alec Mackenzie will come .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: You need n't worry about that , Aunt Alice . He 'll never venture to show his face .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I did n't know what to do . It was impossible to put the dance off . It 's too dreadful that these horrible revelations should ....

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: Supplying the word .Transpire .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Yes , transpire on the very day I 've at last persuaded Lucy to come into the world again . I wish Dick would come .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Yes , he 'll be able to tell us something .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: But will he ?

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: Wherever I go people are talking about Mr. Mackenzie , and I 'm bound to say I 've found nobody who has a good word for him .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Bitterly .Humpty-dumpty 's had a great fall .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: I wonder if I might have a cigarette ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I 'm sure you might . And if you press me dreadfully , I 'll have one , too .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Do n't press her . She 's already had far too many .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Well , I 'll forego the pressing , but not the cigarette .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: Handing her the box and giving her a light .It 's against all my principles , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: What is the use of principles except to give one an agreeable sensation of wickedness when one does n't act up to them ?

div.stage: DICK comes in as she speaks .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My dear lady , you 're as epigrammatic as a dramatist . Do you say such things from choice or necessity ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Dick !

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Dick !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Mr. Lomas !

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: Ah !

div.stage: The four exclamations are simultaneous .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: This enthusiasm at my appearance is no less gratifying than unexpected .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I 'm so glad you 've come at last . Now we shall get at the truth .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Impatiently .Well ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My dear people , what are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Oh , do n't be such an ass !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Good heavens , did n't you read the Times this morning ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I only came back from Paris to-night . Besides , I never read the papers except in August .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Raising her eyebrows .When there 's nothing in them ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Pardon me , I 'm an eager student of the sea-serpent and the giant gooseberry .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: My dear Dick , it 's too shocking . I wish I 'd had the courage to write and ask Mr. Mackenzie not to come . But since you both came back from Africa a month ago he 's been here nearly every day . And he 's been so good and kind to us , I could n't treat him as though there was no doubt the story was true .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: There can n't be the least doubt about it . By George , I should like to kick him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Dryly .My dear chap , Alec is a hardy Scot and bigger than you , so I should n't advise you to try .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I was engaged to dine with him to-night , but I wired to say I had a headache .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: What will he think if he sees you here ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: He can think what he jolly well likes .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I hope he has the sense to stay away .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: I think you 're pretty safe now , Lady Kelsey . It 's growing late .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Will some one kindly explain ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: D'you mean to say you really do n't know — seriously ? After all , you were with him .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: My dear Dick , there are two columns of fiery denunciation in this morning 's Times .

div.stage: DICK is a little startled , but at once collects himself .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , that 's only the reaction . That 's nothing . Since he arrived in Mombassa , after three years in the heart of Africa , he 's made almost a triumphal progress . Of course , it could n't last . The reaction was bound to come .

lg.l: The article is signed by a man named
Macinnery .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Calmly .Alec found Macinnery half starving at Mombassa , and took him solely out of charity . But he was a worthless rascal , and he had to send him back .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: He gives ample proof for every word he says .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Whenever an explorer comes home , there 's some one to tell nasty stories about him . People forget that kid gloves are not much use in a tropical forest , and grow very indignant when they hear that a man has used a little brute force to make himself respected .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Oh , my dear Dick , it 's much worse than that . First poor Lucy 's father died ....

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You 're not going to count that as an overwhelming misfortune ? We were unanimous in describing that gentleman 's demise as an uncommonly happy release .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: But Lucy was heart-broken all the same . And when her life seemed to grow a little more cheerful , came her brother 's tragic death .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Abruptly , to MRS. CROWLEY .What is it exactly ?

lg.l: The long and short of it is that Mr. Mackenzie was the cause of George
Allerton 's death .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Lucy 's brother was killed by the slave-traders .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Mackenzie sent him into a confounded trap to save his own dirty skin .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: And the worst of it is that I think Lucy is in love with Mr. Mackenzie .

div.stage: BOULGER makes a slight movement , and for a moment there is an uncomfortable pause .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: I saw him this evening in Piccadilly , and I almost ran into his arms . It was quite awkward .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Frigidly .Why ?

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: I do n't think I want to shake the man 's hand . He 's nothing short of a murderer .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Savagely .He 's worse than that . He 's ten times worse .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Well , for heaven 's sake be polite to him if he comes to-night .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: I really could n't bring myself to shake hands with him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Dryly .Do n't you think you 'd better wait for evidence before you condemn him ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: My dear fellow , the letter in the Times is absolutely damning . Interviewers went to him from the evening papers , and he refused to see them .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What does Lucy say of it ? After all , she 's the person most concerned .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: She does n't know . I took care that she should n't see the paper . I wanted to give her this evening 's enjoyment unalloyed .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Take care , here she is .

div.stage: LUCY comes in .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Smiling and reaching out her hand .Well , darling ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Going to LADY KELSEY .Are you growing very tired , my aunt ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I can rest myself for the time . I do n't think any one else will come now .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Gaily .You faithless woman , have you forgotten the guest of the evening ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Mr. Mackenzie ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Bending over her .My dear , it was charming of you to hide the paper from me this morning ....

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Startled .Did you see the letter ? I so wanted you not to till to-morrow .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Mr. Mackenzie very rightly thought I should know at once what was said about him and my brother . He sent me the paper himself this evening .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Did he write to you ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No , he merely scribbled on a card : “ I think you should read this . ”

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Well , I 'm damned !

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: What did you think of the letter , Lucy ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Proudly .I did n't believe it .

lg.l: You must be blinded by your — friendship for Alec
Mackenzie . I never read anything more convincing .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I could hardly believe him guilty of such an odious crime if he confessed it with his own lips .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Of course , he wo n't do that .

lg.l: Did I ever tell you how I made acquaintance with Alec ? In the
Atlantic — about three hundred miles from land .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: What a perfectly ridiculous place for an introduction .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I was a silly young fool in those days , and I habitually played the giddy goat . In the course of which , I fell overboard and was proceeding to drown when Alec jumped in after me . It was an incautious thing to do , because he very nearly got drowned himself .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: That 's not the only heroic thing he 's done .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No , it 's one of his hobbies to risk his life to save unnecessary and useless people . But the funny thing is that ever since he saved mine , he 's been quite absurdly grateful . He seems to think I did him an intentional service and fell into the water on purpose to give him a chance of pulling me out .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: With a long look at DICK .It 's very kind and good of you to have told that story .

div.stage: The BUTLER comes in and announces ALEC MACKENZIE .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Mr. Mackenzie .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Blandly .Ah , I thought I should find you here , Lady Kelsey .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Shaking hands with him .How d'you do ? We 've just been talking of you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: It 's so late , we were afraid you would n't come . I should have been dreadfully disappointed .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It 's very kind of you to say so . I 've been at the Travellers ’ , reading various appreciations of my own character .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Somewhat embarrassed .Oh , I heard there was something about you in the papers .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: There 's a good deal . I really had no idea the world was so interested in me .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: It 's charming of you to come to-night . I 'm sure you hate dances !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Oh , no , they interest me enormously . I remember , one of the Kings of Uganda gave a dance in my honour . Ten thousand warriors in war-paint . I assure you it was most impressive .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My dear fellow , if paint is the attraction you really need not go much farther than Mayfair .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Pretending for the first time to notice BOULGER .Ah , there 's my little friend Bobbie . I thought you had a headache ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Quickly .I 'm afraid Bobby is dreadfully dissipated . He 's not looking at all well .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Good-humouredly .You should n't keep such late hours , Bobbie . At your age one wants one 's beauty sleep .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: It 's very kind of you to take an interest in me . My headache has passed off .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm very glad . What do you use — Phenacetin ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: It went away of its own accord — after dinner .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Smiling .So you resolved to give the girls a treat by coming to Lady Kelsey 's dance ? How nice of you not to disappoint them !He turns to LUCY and holds out his hand . They look into one another 's eyes . She takes his hand .I sent you a paper this evening .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: It was very good of you .

div.stage: CARBERY comes forward and offers his arm .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: I think this is my dance , Miss Allerton . May I take you in ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Carbery ? I saw you in Piccadilly just now ! You were darting about just like a young gazelle . I had no idea you could be so active .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: I did n't see you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I observed that you were deeply interested in the shop windows as I passed . How are you ?

div.stage: He holds out his hand , and for a moment CARBERY hesitates to take it . But ALEC 'S steady gaze compels him .

sp.speaker: CARBERY
sp.p: How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With an amused smile .So glad to see you again , old man .

div.stage: DICK gives an audible chuckle , and CARBERY , reddening , draws his hand away angrily . He goes to LUCY and offers his arm .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: To MRS. CROWLEY .Shall I take you back ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Do !

sp.speaker: LADY KESLEY
sp.p: Wo n't you come , Mr. Mackenzie ?

lg.l: If you do n't mind I 'll stay and smoke just one cigarette with Dick
Lomas . You know I 'm not a dancing man .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Very well .

div.stage: All go out except ALEC and DICK .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I suppose you know we were all beseeching Providence you 'd have the grace to stay away to-night ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a smile .I suspected it , I confess . I should n't have come only I wanted to see Lucy . I 've been in the country all day , and I knew nothing about Macinnery 's letter till I saw the placards at the station .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Macinnery proposes to make things rather uncomfortable , I imagine .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a smile .I made a mistake , did n't I ? I ought to have dropped him in the river when I had no further use for him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It 's not easy to clear myself at a dead man 's expense . The earth covers his crime and his sins and his weakness .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: D'you mean to say that you are going to sit still and let them throw mud at you ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: When George was dead I wrote to Lucy that he died like a brave man . I can n't now publish to the whole world that he was a coward and a rogue . I can n't rake up again the story of her father 's crime .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Impatiently .Surely , that 's absolutely quixotic .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No , it is n't . I tell you I can n't do anything else . I 'm bound hand and foot . Lucy has talked to me of George 's death , and the only thing that has consoled her is the idea that in a manner he had redeemed his father 's good name . How can I rob her of that ? She placed all her hopes in George . How could she face the world with the knowledge that her brother was rotten to the core , as rotten as her father .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It seems awfully hard .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Besides , when all is said and done , the boy did die game . Do n't you think that should count for something ? No , I tell you I can n't give him away now . I should never cease to reproach myself . I love Lucy far too much to cause her such bitter pain .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And if it loses you her love ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I think she can do without love better than without self-respect .

div.stage: LUCY comes in with MRS. CROWLEY .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I 've sent my partner away . I felt I must have a few words alone with you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Shall I take Mrs. Crowley into a retired corner ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No , we have nothing to say that you can n't hear . You and Nellie know that we 're engaged to be married .To ALEC .I want you to dance with me .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It 's very good of you .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Do n't you think that 's rather foolish , Lucy ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: To ALEC .I want to show them all that I do n't believe that you 're guilty of an odious crime .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: They 've said horrible things about me ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Not to me . They wanted to hide it from me , but I knew they were talking .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You 'll grow used to hearing shameful things said of me . I suppose I shall grow used to it , too .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , I hate them .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Ah , it 's not that I mind . What torments me is that it was so easy to despise their praise , and now I can n't despise their blame .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Smiling .I believe you have some glimmerings of human nature in you after all .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: When you came to-night , so calm and self-possessed , I admired you as I 'd never admired you before .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It 's easy enough to command one 's face . I learnt to do that in Africa when often my life depended on my seeming to have no fear . But in my heart ... I never knew that I could feel so bitter . And yet , after all , it 's only your good opinion that I care for .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I 've trusted you implicitly from the first day I saw you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Thank God for that ! To-day is the first time I 've wanted to be assured that I was trusted . And yet I 'm ashamed to want it .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Ah , do n't be too hard upon yourself . You 're so afraid of letting your tenderness appear .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: The only way to be strong is never to surrender to one 's weakness . Strength is merely a habit like everything else . I want you to be strong , too . I want you never to doubt me whatever you may hear said .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I gave my brother into your hands , and told you that if he died a brave man 's death I could ask for no more .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I should tell you that I 've made up my mind to make no answer to the charges that are made against me .

div.stage: There is a very short pause , while he looks at her steadily .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: But why ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: To LUCY .I can give you my word of honour that I 've done nothing which I regret . I know that what I did was right with regard to George , and if it were all to come again I would do exactly as I did before .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I think I can trust you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I thought of you always , and everything I did was for your sake . Every single act of mine during these four years in Africa has been done because I loved you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You must love me always , Alec , for now I have only you .He bends down and kisses her hand .Come !

div.stage: He gives her his arm and they walk out .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I feel as if I should rather like to cry .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Do you really ? So do I .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Do n't be so silly .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: By the way , you do n't want to dance with me , do you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Certainly not . You dance abominably .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's charming of you to say so . It puts me at my ease at once .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Come and sit on the sofa and talk seriously .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Ah , you want to flirt with me , Mrs. Crowley .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Good heavens , what on earth makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's what a woman always means when she asks you to talk sensibly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I can n't bear a man who thinks women are in love with him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Bless you , I do n't think that . I only think they want to marry me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: That 's equally detestable .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Not at all . However old , ugly , and generally undesirable a man is , he 'll find a heap of charming girls who are willing to marry him . Marriage is still the only decent means of livelihood for a really nice girl .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: But , my dear friend , if a woman really makes up her mind to marry a man , nothing on earth can save him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Do n't say that , you terrify me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You need not be in the least alarmed , because I shall refuse you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Thanks , awfully . But all the same I do n't think I 'll risk a proposal .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: My dear Mr. Lomas , your only safety is in immediate flight .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: It must be obvious to the meanest intelligence that you 've been on the verge of proposing to me for the last month .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , I assure you , you 're quite mistaken .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Then I sha n't come to the play with you to-morrow ?

lg.l: But I 've taken the seats , and I 've ordered an exquisite dinner at the
Carlton .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: What have you ordered ?

lg.l: Potage Bisque ...
Sole Normande ...
Wild Duck .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: With an orange salad ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I do n't positively dislike that .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And I 've ordered a souffle with an ice in the middle of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I sha n't come .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I should n't have thought you kept very well abreast of dramatic art if you insist on marrying every man who takes you to a theatre .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Demurely .I was very nicely brought up .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Of course , if you 're going to make yourself systematically disagreeable unless I marry you , I suppose I shall have to do it in self-defence .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I do n't know if you have the least idea what you 're talking about . I 'm sure I have n't !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I was merely asking you in a rather well-turned phrase to name the day . The lamb shall be ready for the slaughter !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Could n't you infuse a little romance into it ? You might begin by going down on your bended knees .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I assure you that 's quite out of fashion . Lovers , nowadays , are much too middle-aged , and their joints are creaky . Besides , it ruins the trousers .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: At all events , there can be no excuse for your not saying that you know you 're utterly unworthy of me .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Wild horses would n't induce me to make a statement which is so remote from the truth .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: And , of course , you must threaten to commit suicide if I do n't consent .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Women are such sticklers for routine . They have no originality .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Very well , have it your own way . But I must have a proposal in due form .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Only four words are needed .Counting them on his fingers .Will you marry me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: That is both clear and simple . I reply in one : No !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: As though he were not sure that he had heard correctly .I beg your pardon ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: The answer is in the negative .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You 're joking . You 're certainly joking .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I will be a sister to you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Do you mean to say you deliberately refuse me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Smiling .I promised you I would .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: With much seriousness .I thank you from the bottom of my heart .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Puzzled .The man 's mad . The man 's nothing short of a raving lunatic .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I wanted to see if you were really attached to me . You have given me a proof of esteem which I promise you I will never forget .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Laughing .You 're a perfect idiot , Mr. Lomas !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's one of my cherished convictions that a really nice woman is never so cruel as to marry a man she cares for .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You 're much too flippant to marry anybody , and you 're perfectly odious into the bargain .

div.stage: She goes out . DICK , chuckling , lights a cigarette . ALEC comes in and lies down lazily on the sofa .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Why , Dick , what 's the matter ? You look as pleased as Punch .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My dear fellow , I feel like the Terrible Turk . I 've been wrestling , and I thought I was going to have a fall . But by the display of considerable agility I 've managed to keep my legs .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Nothing . It 's merely the gaiety of forty-two .

div.stage: BOULGER comes into the room , followed immediately by MALLINS and CARBERY . He starts slightly when he sees ALEC , but then goes over to the table on which is the whiskey .

sp.speaker: MALLINS
sp.p: May we smoke here , Bobby ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Certainly . Dick insisted that this room should be particularly reserved for that purpose .

div.stage: The BUTLER comes in with a small silver salver , and takes up one or two dirty glasses .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Lady Kelsey is the most admirable of all hostesses .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Taking a cigarette from his case .Give me a match , Bobby , there 's a good boy .BOULGER , with his back turned to ALEC , takes no notice . He pours himself out some whiskey . ALEC smiles slightly .Bobby , throw me over the matches !

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: With his back still turned .Miller !

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Yes , sir ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Mr. Mackenzie is asking for something .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Yes , sir !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You might give me a light , will you ?

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Yes , sir !

div.stage: The BUTLER takes the matches to ALEC , who lights his cigarette .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Thank you .Complete silence is preserved till the BUTLER leaves the room .I perceive , Bobbie , that during my absence you have not added good manners to your other accomplishments .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: If you want things , you can ask the servants for them .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Do n't be foolish , Bobbie !

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Would you be so kind as to remember that my name is Boulger ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Smiling .Perhaps you would like me to call you Sir Robert ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I should prefer that you would call me nothing at all . I have absolutely no wish to know you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Which shows that your taste is as bad as your breeding .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Angrily , walking up to him .By God , I 'll knock you down !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You could hardly do that when I 'm already lying on my back .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Look here , Mackenzie , I 'm not going to let you play the fool with me . I want to know what answer you have to make to all these charges that have been brought against you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Might I suggest that only Miss Allerton has the least right to receive answers to her questions ? And she has n't questioned me .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I 've given up trying to understand her attitude . If I were she , it would make me sick with horror to look at you . Since this morning you 've rested under a direct accusation of causing George 's death , and you 've said nothing in self-defence .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: You 've been given an opportunity to explain yourself , and you have n't taken it .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Quite true .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Are you not going to deny the charge ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm not .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Then I can only draw one conclusion . There appears to be no means of bringing you to justice , but at least I can refuse to know you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: All is over between us . And shall I return your letters and your photograph ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I 'm not joking .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It 's singular that though I 'm Scotch and you are English I should be able to see how ridiculous you are , while you 're quite blind to your own absurdity .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Come , Alec ! Remember he 's only a boy .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: To DICK LOMAS .I 'm perfectly able to look after myself , and I 'll thank you not to interfere .To ALEC .If Lucy 's so indifferent to her brother 's death that she 's willing to keep up with you , that 's her own affair ...

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Interrupting .Come , Bobbie , do n't make a scene .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Furiously .Leave me alone , confound you !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do you think this is quite the place for an altercation ? Would n't you gain more notoriety if you attacked me in my club or at Church parade on Sunday ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: It 's mere shameless impudence that you should come here to-night . You 're using these wretched women as a shield , because you know that as long as Lucy sticks to you there are people who wo n't believe the story .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I came for the same reason as yourself , dear boy . Because I was invited .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Now then , Bobbie , shut up !

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I sha n't shut up . The man 's got no right to force himself here .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Remember that you 're Lady Kelsey 's nephew .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I did n't ask him . D'you think I 'd have come if I knew he was going to be here ? He 's acknowledged that he has no defence .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Pardon me , I acknowledge nothing and deny nothing .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: That wo n't do for me . I want the truth , and I 'm going to get it . I 've got a right to know .

sp.speaker: ALEC
