sp.p: Beginning to lose his temper .Do n't make an ass of yourself , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: By God , I 'll make you answer !

div.stage: As he says this he goes up to ALEC furiously , but ALEC . with a twist of his arm , hurls him back .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I could break your back , you silly boy .

div.stage: With a cry of anger BOULGER is about to spring at ALEC when DICK gets in the way .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Now then , no scenes . And you 'll only get the worst of it , Bobby . Alec could just crumple you up . Take him away , Mallins . Do n't stand there like a stuffed owl , Carbery .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Let me alone , you fool !

sp.speaker: MALLINS
sp.p: Come along , old chap .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: To ALEC .You damned skunk !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Now then , be off with you . Do n't make a silly ass of yourself .

div.stage: BOULGER , MALLINS and CARBERY go out .

lg.l: Poor Lady Kelsey ! To-morrow half London will be saying that you and
Bobby had a stand-up fight in her drawing-room .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Furiously .The damned cubs !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: The position is growing confoundedly awkward !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: They lick my boots till I loathe them , and then they turn against me like a pack of curs . Oh , I despise them — these silly boys who stay at home wallowing in their ease while men work . Thank God , I 've done with them all now . They think one can fight one 's way through Africa as easily as one walks down Piccadilly . They think one goes through hardships and dangers , illness and starvation , to be the lion of a dinner-party in Mayfair .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My dear Alec , keep calm .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a visible effort containing himself completely , with studied nonchalance .D'you think that I look wildly excited ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Ironically .I do n't think butter would melt in your mouth .

div.stage: DICK and ALEC go out into the garden . In a moment BOULGER comes in with LADY KELSEY .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Thank heaven , there 's nobody here .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I think you 're dreadfully foolish , Bobby . You know how Lucy resents any interference with her actions .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Wo n't you sit down ? You must be dreadfully tired .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Why wo n't you wait till to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I feel that it ought to be settled at once .

div.stage: LUCY appears .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Did you send for me , my aunt ? Mr. Carbery said you wanted to speak to me here .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Yes , I gave him that message .

lg.l: I asked Aunt Alice to beg you to come here . I was afraid you would n't if
I asked you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Lightly .What nonsense ! I 'm always delighted to see you .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I wanted to speak to you about something , and I thought Aunt Alice should be present .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Is it so important that it can n't wait till to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I venture to think it 's very important .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Smiling .I 'm all attention .

div.stage: He hesitates for a moment , then braces himself to the ordeal .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I 've told you often , Lucy , that I 've been in love with you for as many years as I can remember .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Surely you 've not snatched me from the unwilling arm of my partner in order to make me a proposal of marriage ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I 'm perfectly serious , Lucy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Smiling .I assure you it does n't suit you at all .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: The other day I asked you again to marry me , just before Alec Mackenzie came back .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: It was very charming of you . You must n't think that because I laugh at you a little I 'm not grateful for your affection .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Except for that letter in this morning 's Times , I should never have dared to say anything to you again . But that changes everything .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I do n't understand what you mean .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: After a little pause .I ask you again if you 'll be my wife ? When Alec Mackenzie came back I understood why you were so indifferent to me , but you can n't marry him now .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You have no right to talk to me like this .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I 'm the only man who 's related to you at all , and I love you with my whole soul .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I think you should listen to him , Lucy . I 'm growing old , and soon you 'll be quite alone in the world .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: I do n't ask you to care for me . I only want to serve you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I can only repeat that I 'm very grateful to you . I can never marry you .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Beginning to lose his temper again .Are you going to continue to know Mackenzie ? If you 'll take the advice of any unprejudiced person about that letter , you 'll find that he 'll say the same as I . There can be no shadow of doubt that Mackenzie is guilty of a monstrous crime .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I do n't care what the evidence is . I know he can n't have done a shameful thing .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: But have you forgotten that it 's your own brother he killed ? The whole country is up in arms against him , and you are quite indifferent .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Much moved .Oh , Bobbie , how can you be so cruel ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: If you ever really cared for George at all , you must wish to punish the man who caused his death .

lg.l: Oh , why d'you torment me ? I tell you that he is n't guilty . It 's because
I 'm convinced of that ...

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Interrupting .But have you asked him ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: He might give you the truth .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I could n't do that .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: It 's very strange that he should insist on this silence .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Do you believe that story too ?

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I do n't know what to believe . It 's so extraordinary . If the man 's innocent , why does n't he speak ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: He knows I trust him . I could n't cause him the great pain of asking him questions .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Are you afraid he could n't answer them ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No , no , no !

lg.l: Well , just try . After all , you owe as much as that to the memory of
George .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I think it 's very unreasonable , Lucy . He knows we 're his friends . He can count on our discretion .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I believe in him implicitly . I believe in him with all the strength I 've got .

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Then , surely it can make no difference if you ask him . There can be no reason for him not to trust you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , why do n't you leave me alone ?

sp.speaker: BOULGER
sp.p: Ask him point blank . If he refuses to answer you ...

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Hastily .It would mean nothing . Why should he answer ? I believe in him absolutely . I think he 's the greatest and most honourable man I 've ever known . I care more for his little finger than for the whole world . I love him with all my heart . And that 's why he can n't be guilty of this horrible crime . Because I 've loved him for years , and he 's known it . And he loves me . And he 's loved me always .

div.stage: ALEC and DICK stroll in from the garden .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Alec , Alec , I want you ! Thank God , you 've come !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Going to her quickly .What is it ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Alec , you must tell them now about you and me .

div.stage: ALEC looks at LUCY for a moment , and then turns to LADY KELSEY .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I think perhaps we ought to have told you before , Lady Kelsey . But we wanted to enjoy our little secret by ourselves .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: I 'm afraid to understand .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I have asked Lucy to be my wife , and she ....

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Interrupting him .She said she would be honoured and deeply grateful .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Greatly embarrassed .I hardly know what to say .... How long have you been engaged ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Wo n't you tell me you 're pleased , my aunt ? I know you want me to be happy .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Of course , I want you to be happy . But I — I ....

div.stage: BOULGER turns on his heel and walks out .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Offering his arm to LADY KELSEY .Would n't you like to go back to the drawing-room ?

div.stage: She allows herself to be led away , helplessly . ALEC and LUCY are left alone .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a smile .I do n't think our announcement has been received with enthusiasm .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You 're not angry with me , ALEC ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Of course not . Everything you do is right and charming .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I shall really think I 'm a wonderful person if I 've taught you to pay compliments .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm so glad to be alone with you . Now , at all events , people will have the sense to leave us by ourselves .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Passionately .I want your love . I want your love so badly .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Taking her in his arms .My darling !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Clinging to him .The moment I 'm with you I feel so confident and happy .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Only when you 're with me ?LUCY looks at him for an instant . He repeats the question in a caressing voice .Only when you 're with me , darling ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Why d'you think I made you tell them we were engaged ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You took me by surprise .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I had to tell them . I could n't keep it back . They made me suffer so dreadfully .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: The brutes ! Tell me what they did .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , they said horrible things about you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No more than that ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: It 's nothing to you . But to me .... Oh , you do n't know what agony I endure . I 'm such a coward ! I thought I was so much braver .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I do n't understand you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I wanted to burn my ships behind me . I wanted to reassure myself .ALEC makes a slight movement away from her , but she holds him back anxiously .Forgive me , dear . You do n't know how terrible it is . I stand so dreadfully alone . Every one is convinced that you caused poor George 's death — every one but me .ALEC looks at her gravely , without speaking .I try to put the thoughts out of my head , but I can n't — I can n't . That letter in the Times looks so dreadfully true . Do n't you see what I mean ? The uncertainty is more than I can bear . At the first moment I felt so absolutely sure of you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: And now you do n't ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I trust you just as much as ever . I know it 's impossible that you should have done a shameful thing . But there it stands in black and white , and you have nothing to say in answer .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I know it 's very difficult . That is why I asked you to believe in me .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I do , Alec — with all my soul . But have mercy on me . I 'm not so strong as I thought . It 's easy for you to stand alone . You 're iron , but I 'm a weak woman .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Oh , no , you 're not like other women . I was proud of your unconquerable spirit .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: It was easy to be brave where my father was concerned , and George , but you 're the man I love , and it 's so different . I do n't know any more how to stand alone .

div.stage: ALEC looks at her , thinking , but does not reply for a moment .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do you remember that only an hour ago I told you that I 'd done nothing which I would n't do again ? I gave you my word of honour that I could reproach myself for nothing .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , I know . I 'm so utterly ashamed of myself . But I can n't bear the doubt .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Doubt ! You 've said the word at last .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I tell every one that I do n't believe a word of these horrible charges , and I repeat to myself : I 'm certain , I 'm certain that he 's innocent . And yet at the bottom of my heart there 's a doubt , and I can n't crush it .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Is that why you told them we were engaged to be married ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I wanted to kill that gnawing pain of suspicion . I thought if I stood up before them and cried out that my trust in you was so great , I was willing to marry you notwithstanding everything , I should at least have peace in my own heart .

div.stage: ALEC walks up and down . Then he stops in front of LUCY .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: What is it precisely you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I want you to have mercy on me because I love you . Do n't tell the world if you choose not to , but tell me the truth . I know you 're incapable of lying . If I only have it from your own lips I shall believe , I want to be certain , certain !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do n't you realise that I would never have asked you to marry me if my conscience had n't been quite clear ? Do n't you realise that the reasons I have for holding my tongue must be of overwhelming strength ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But I am going to be your wife , and I love you , and you love me .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I implore you not to insist , Lucy . Let us remember only that the past is gone and we love one another . It 's impossible for me to tell you anything .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , but you must now . If any part of the story is true , you must give me a chance of judging for myself .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm very sorry , I can n't .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But you 'll kill my love for you . The doubt which lurked at the bottom of my soul now fills me . How can you let me suffer such maddening torture ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I thought you trusted me .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I 'll be satisfied if you 'll only tell me one thing : only tell me that when you sent George on that expedition you did n't know that he 'd be killed .ALEC looks at her steadily .Only say that , Alec . Say that 's not true , and I 'll believe you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Very quietly .But it is true .

div.stage: LUCY does not answer , but stares at him with terrified eyes .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't understand . Oh , my dearest , do n't treat me as a child . Have mercy on me ! You must be serious now . It 's a matter of life and death to both of us .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm perfectly serious .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You knew that you were sending George into a death-trap ? You knew he could n't escape alive ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Except by a miracle .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And you do n't believe in miracles ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , it can n't be true . Oh , Alec , Alec , Alec ! Oh , what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I tell you that whatever I did was inevitable .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Then if that 's true , the rest must be true also . Oh , it 's awful . I can n't realise it . Have n't you anything to say at all ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: In a low voice .Only that I 've loved you always with all my soul .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You knew how much I loved my brother . You knew how much it meant to me that he should live to wipe out my father 's dishonour . All the future was centred on him , and you sacrificed him .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Hesitatingly .I think I might tell you this . He had committed a grave error of judgment . We were entrapped by the Arabs , and our only chance of escape entailed the almost certain death of one of us .

div.stage: An inkling of the truth seizes LUCY , and her face is suddenly distorted with horror . She goes up to him impulsively . Her voice trembles with emotion .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Alec , Alec , he did n't do something — unworthy ? You 're not trying to shield him ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Hoarsely .No , no , no !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: With a gasp of relief , almost to herself .Thank God ! I could n't have borne that .To ALEC , hopelessly .Then I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It was not unjust that he should suffer for the catastrophe which he had brought about .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: At those times one does n't think of justice . He was so young , so frank . Would n't it have been nobler to give your life for his ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Oh , my dear , you do n't know how easy it is to give one 's life . How little you know me ! Do you think I should have hesitated if my death had been sufficient to solve the difficulty ? I had my work to do . I was bound by solemn treaties to the surrounding tribes . It would have been cowardly for me to die . I tell you , my death would have meant the awful death of every man in my party .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I can only see one thing , that you took George , George of all others .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I knew at the time that what I did might cost me your love , and though you wo n't believe this , I did it for your sake .

div.stage: At this moment MRS. CROWLEY enters with SIR ROBERT BOULGER . She has a cloak on .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I was just coming to say good-night . Bobby is going to drive me home .She suddenly notices LUCY 'S agitation .What on earth 's the matter ?

div.stage: LADY KELSEY and DICK LOMAS come in . LADY KELSEY looks at LUCY and then goes up to her impulsively .

sp.speaker: LADY KELSEY
sp.p: Lucy , Lucy !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Brokenly .I 'm no longer engaged to Mr. Mackenzie . He can n't deny that what is said about him is true .

div.stage: They look at him in astonishment , but he makes no movement .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: To ALEC .Have n't you anything to say at all ? You must have some explanation to offer ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No , I have none whatever .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Alec , old man , have you realised all that this means ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Quite . I see now that it was inevitable .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: With a sudden burst of furious anger .You killed him ! You killed him as surely as if you 'd strangled him with your own hands .

div.stage: ROBERT BOULGER goes to the door and flings it open . ALEC gives LUCY a look , then slightly shrugs his shoulders . He walks out without a word . The moment he has gone LUCY sinks down and bursts into passionate tears .

sp.speaker: END OF THE THIRD ACT
sp.p: THE FOURTH ACT

sp.speaker: SCENE .— A library in the house of DICK LOMAS in Portman Square
sp.p: DICK and his VALET . DICK is putting flowers into a vase .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Has Mr. Mackenzie come in ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Yes , sir . He 's gone to his room .

lg.l: I expect Mrs. Crowley and Miss Allerton to tea . If any one else comes
I 'm not at home .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Very well , sir .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And if a caller should ask at what time I 'm expected back , you have n't the least idea .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Very well , sir .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: We shall want breakfast at eight to-morrow . I 'm going down to Southampton to see Mr. Mackenzie off . But I shall be home to dinner . How about those cases in the hall ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Mr. Mackenzie said they were to be sent for this afternoon . They 're only labelled Zanzibar . Is that sufficient , sir ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , I suppose so . Mr. Mackenzie will have given the shippers all directions . You 'd better bring the tea at once . Mrs. Crowley is coming at four .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Very well , sir .

div.stage: He goes out . DICK continues to arrange the flowers , than goes to the window and looks out . He comes back . The door is opened by CHARLES , who announces MRS. CROWLEY .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Mrs. Crowley .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Going towards her eagerly and taking both her hands .Best of women !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You seem quite glad to see me ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I am . But where is Lucy ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: She 's coming later .... I do n't know why you should squeeze my hands in this pointed manner .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What an age it is since I saw you !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: If you bury yourself in Scotland all the summer , you can n't expect to see people who go to Homburg and the Italian lakes .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Heavens , how you cultivate respectability !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: It 's a sensitive plant whose vagaries one has to humour .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Are n't you delighted to be back in town ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: London 's the most charming place in the world to get away from and to come back to . Now tell me all you 've been doing , if I can hear it without blushing too furiously .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: My behaviour would have done credit to a clergyman 's only daughter . I dragged Alec off to Scotland after that horrible scene at Lady Kelsey 's , and we played golf .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Was he very wretched , poor thing ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: He did n't say a word . I wanted to comfort him , but he never gave me a chance . He never mentioned Lucy 's name .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Did he seem unhappy ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No . He was just the same as ever , impassive and collected .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Really he 's inhuman .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: He 's an anomaly in this juvenile century . He 's an ancient Roman who buys his clothes in Savile Row . An eagle caged with a colony of canaries .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Then he 's very much in the way in England , and it 's much better for him that he should go back to Africa .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: This time to-morrow he 'll be half-way down the channel .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I 'm really beginning to think you 're a perfect angel , Mr. Lomas .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Do n't say that , it makes me feel so middle-aged . I 'd much sooner be a young sinner than an elderly cherub .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: It was sweet of you to look after him through the summer and then insist on his staying here till he went away . How long is he going for this time ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Heaven knows ! Perhaps for ever .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Have you told him that Lucy is coming ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No . I thought that was a pleasing piece of information which I 'd leave you to impart .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Thanks !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: She 's only coming to indulge a truly feminine passion for making scenes , and she 's made Alec quite wretched enough already . Why does n't she marry Robert Boulger ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Why should she ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Half the women I know merely married their husbands to spite somebody else . It appears to be one of the commonest causes of matrimony .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: With a quizzical look at him .Talking of which , what are you going to do when Mr. Mackenzie is gone ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Talking of the weather and the crops , I propose to go to Spain .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Opening her eyes wide .How very extraordinary ! I thought of going there , too .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Then , without a moment 's hesitation , I shall go to Norway .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: It 'll be dreadfully cold .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Dreadfully . But I shall be supported by the consciousness of having done my duty .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You do n't think there would be room for both of us in Spain ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I 'm convinced there would n't . We should always be running against one another , and you 'd insist on my looking out all your trains in Bradshaw .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I hope you remember that you asked me to tea to-day ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Pardon me , you asked yourself . I keep the letter next to my heart and put it under my pillow every night .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You fibber ! Besides , if I did , it was only on Lucy 's account .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: That , I venture to think , is neither polite nor accurate .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I do n't think I should so utterly detest you , if you had n't such a good opinion of yourself .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You forget that I vowed on the head of my maternal grandmother never to speak to you again .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Oh , I 'm always doing that . I tell my maid that time she does my hair badly .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You trifled with the tenderest affection of an innocent and unsophisticated old bachelor .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Is that you by any chance ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Of course , it 's me . D'you think I was talking of the man in the moon ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Looking at him critically .With the light behind , you might still pass for thirty-five .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I 've given up youth and its vanities . I no longer pluck out my white hairs .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Then how on earth do you occupy your leisure ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: For the last three months I 've been laboriously piecing together the fragments of a broken heart .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: If you had n't been so certain that I was going to accept you , I should never have refused . I could n't resist the temptation of saying “ No ” just to see how you took it .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I flatter myself that I took it very well .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You did n't . You showed an entire lack of humour . You might have known that a nice woman does n't marry a man the first time he asks her . It 's making oneself too cheap . It was very silly of you to go off to Scotland as if you did n't care .... How was I to know that you meant to wait three months before asking me again ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I have n't the least intention of asking you again .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Then why in heaven 's name did you invite me to tea ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: May I respectfully remind you , first , that you invited yourself ...

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Interrupting .You 're so irrelevant .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And , secondly , that an invitation to tea is not necessarily accompanied by a proposal of marriage .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 're lamentably ignorant of the usages of good society .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I assure you it 's not done in the best circles .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: With a little pout .I shall be very cross with you in a minute .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Because you 're not behaving at all prettily .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: D'you know what I 'd do if I were you ? Propose to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Oh , I could n't do anything so immodest .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I have registered a vow that I will never offer my hand and heart to any woman again .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: On the head of your maternal grandmother ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh no , far more serious than that . On the grave of my maiden aunt , who left me all my money .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: What will you say if I do ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: That depends entirely on how you do it . I may remind you , however , that first you go down on your bended knees .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Oh , I waived that with you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And then you confess you 're unworthy of me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Mr. Lomas , I am a widow . I am twenty-nine and extremely eligible . My maid is a treasure . My dressmaker is charming . I am clever enough to laugh at your jokes , and not so learned as to know where they come from .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Really you 're very long-winded . I said it all in four words .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: So could I if I might write it down .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You must say it .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: But what I 'm trying to make you understand is that I do n't want to marry you a bit . You 're just the sort of man who 'll beat his wife regularly every Saturday night .... You will say yes if I ask you , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I 've never been able to refuse a woman anything .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I have no doubt you will after six months of holy matrimony .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I never saw any one make such a fuss about so insignificant a detail as a proposal of marriage .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Dick .She stretches out her hands , smiling , and he takes her in his arms .You really are a detestable person .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: With a smile , taking a ring from his pocket .I bought an engagement ring yesterday on the off chance of its being useful .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Then you meant to ask me all the time ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Of course I did , you silly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Oh , I wish I had known that before . I 'd have refused you again .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You absurd creature .

div.stage: He kisses her .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Trying to release herself .There 's somebody coming .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's only Alec .

div.stage: ALEC comes in .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Hulloa !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Alec , we 've made friends , Mrs. Crowley and I .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It certainly looks very much like it .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: The fact is , I 've asked her to marry me , and she ....

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Interrupting , with a smile .After much pressure —

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Has consented .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm so glad . I heartily congratulate you both . I was rather unhappy at leaving Dick , Mrs. Crowley . But now I leave him in your hands , I 'm perfectly content . He 's the dearest , kindest old chap I 've ever known .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Shut up , Alec ! Do n't play the heavy father , or we shall burst into tears .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: He 'll be an admirable husband because he 's an admirable friend .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I know he will . And I 'm only prevented from saying all I think of him and how much I love him , by the fear that he 'll become perfectly unmanageable .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Spare me these chaste blushes which mantle my youthful brow . Will you pour out the tea ... Nellie ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Yes ... Dick .

div.stage: She sits down at the tea-table and DICK makes himself comfortable in an arm-chair by her side .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Well , I 'm thankful to say that everything 's packed and ready .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: I wish you 'd stay for our wedding .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Do . You can go just as well by the next boat .

lg.l: I 'm afraid that everything is settled now . I 've given instructions at
Zanzibar to collect bearers , and I must arrive as quickly as I can .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I wish to goodness you 'd give up these horrible explorations .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: But they 're the very breath of my life . You do n't know the exhilaration of the daily dangers — the joy of treading where only the wild beasts have trodden before . Oh , already I can hardly bear my impatience when I think of the boundless country and the enchanting freedom . Here one grows so small , so despicable , but in Africa everything is built to a nobler standard . There a man is really a man ; there one knows what are will and strength and courage . Oh , you do n't know what it is to stand on the edge of some great plain and breathe the pure keen air after the terrors of the forest . Then at last you know what freedom is .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: The boundless plain of Hyde Park is enough for me , and the aspect of Piccadilly on a fine day in June gives me quite as many emotions as I want .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: But what will you gain by it all , now that your work in East Africa is over , by all the dangers and the hardships ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Nothing . I want to gain nothing . Perhaps I shall discover some new species of antelope or some unknown plant . Perhaps I shall find some new waterway . That is all the reward I want . I love the sense of power and mastery . What do you think I care for the tinsel rewards of kings and peoples ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I always said you were melodramatic . I never heard anything so transpontine .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: And the end of it , what will be the end ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: The end is death in some fever-stricken swamp , obscurely , worn out by exposure and ague and starvation . And the bearers will seize my gun and my clothes and leave me to the jackals .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Do n't . It 's too horrible .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Why , what does it matter ? I shall die standing up . I shall go the last journey as I have gone every other .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Without fear ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: For all the world like the wicked baronet : Once aboard the lugger and the girl is mine !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Do n't you want men to remember you ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Perhaps they will . Perhaps in a hundred years or so , in some flourishing town where I discovered nothing but wilderness , they will commission a second-rate sculptor to make a fancy statue of me . And I shall stand in front of the Stock Exchange , a convenient perch for birds , to look eternally upon the various shabby deeds of human kind .

div.stage: During this speech MRS. CROWLEY makes a sign to DICK , who walks slowly away and goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: And is that really everything ? I can n't help thinking that at the bottom of your heart is something that you 've never told to a living soul .

div.stage: He gives her a long look , and then after a moment 's thought breaks into a little smile .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Why do you want to know so much ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Tell me .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I daresay I shall never see you again . Perhaps it does n't much matter what I say to you . You 'll think me very silly , but I 'm afraid I 'm rather — patriotic . It 's only we who live away from England who really love it . I 'm so proud of my country , and I wanted so much to do something for it . Often in Africa I 've thought of this dear England , and longed not to die till I had done my work . Behind all the soldiers and the statesmen whose fame is imperishable , there is a long line of men who 've built up the Empire piece by piece . Their names are forgotten , and only students know their history , but each one of them gave a province to his country . And I , too , have my place among them . For five years I toiled night and day , and at the end of it was able to hand over to the Commissioners a broad tract of land , rich and fertile . After my death England will forget my faults and my mistakes . I care nothing for the flouts and gibes with which she has repaid all my pain , for I have added another fair jewel to her crown . I do n't want rewards . I only want the honour of serving this dear land of ours .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Why is it , when you 're so nice really , that you do all you can to make people think you utterly horrid ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do n't laugh at me because you 've found out that at heart I 'm nothing more than a sentimental old woman .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Putting her hand on his arm .What would you do if Lucy came here to-day ?

div.stage: ALEC starts , looks at her sharply , then answers with deliberation .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I have always lived in polite society . I should never dream of outraging its conventions . If Miss Allerton happened to come , you may be sure I should be scrupulously polite .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Is that all ? Lucy has suffered very much .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: And do you suppose I 've not suffered ? Because I do n't whine my misery to all and sundry , d'you think I do n't care ? I 'm not the man to fall in and out of love with every pretty face I meet . All my life I 've kept an ideal before my eyes . Oh , you do n't know what it meant to me to fall in love . I felt that I had lived all my life in a prison , and at last Lucy came and took me by the hand and led me out . And for the first time I breathed the free air of heaven . Oh God ! how I 've suffered for it ! Why should it have come to me ? Oh , if you knew my agony and the torture !

div.stage: He hides his face , trying to master his emotion . MRS. CROWLEY goes to him and puts her hand on his shoulder .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Mr. Mackenzie .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Springing up .Go away . Do n't look at me . How can you stand there and watch my weakness ? Oh God , give me strength .... My love was the last human weakness I had . It was right that I should drink that bitter cup . And I 've drunk its very dregs . I should have known that I was n't meant for happiness and a life of ease . I have other work to do in the world . And now that I have overcome this last temptation , I am ready to do it .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: But have n't you any pity for yourself , have n't you any thought for Lucy ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Must I tell you , too , that everything I did was for Lucy 's sake ? And still I love her with all my heart and soul ....

sp.speaker: DICK comes in
sp.p: DICK . Here is Lucy !

div.stage: CHARLES comes in and announces LUCY .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Miss Allerton !

div.stage: She enters , and DICK , anxious that the meeting shall not be more awkward than need be , goes up to her very cordially .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Ah , my dear Lucy . So glad you were able to come .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Giving her hand to DICK , but looking at ALEC .How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: How d'you do ?He forces himself to talk .How is Lady Kelsey ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: She 's much better , thanks . We 've been to Spa , you know , for her health .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Somebody told me you 'd gone abroad . Was it you , Dick ? Dick is an admirable person , a sort of gazetteer for polite society .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Wo n't you have some tea , Lucy ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No , thanks !

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: Trying on her side also to make conversation .We shall miss you dreadfully when you 're gone , Mr. Mackenzie .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Cheerfully .Not a bit of it .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Smiling .London is an excellent place for showing one of how little importance one is in the world . One makes a certain figure , and perhaps is tempted to think oneself of some consequence . Then one goes away , and on returning is surprised to discover that nobody has even noticed one 's absence .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You 're over-modest , Alec . If you were n't , you might be a great man . Now , I make a point of telling my friends that I 'm indispensable , and they take me at my word .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You are a leaven of flippancy in the heavy dough of British righteousness .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: The wise man only takes the unimportant quite seriously .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: With a smile .For it is obvious that it needs more brains to do nothing than to be a cabinet minister .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You pay me a great compliment , Alec . You repeat to my very face one of my favourite observations .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Almost in a whisper .Have n't I heard you say that only the impossible is worth doing ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Good heavens , I must have been reading the headings of a copy-book .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: To DICK .Are you going to Southampton to see Mr. Mackenzie off ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I shall hide my face on his shoulder and weep salt tears . It 'll be most affecting , because in moments of emotion I always burst into epigram .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I loathe all solemn leave-takings . I prefer to part from people with a nod and a smile , whether I 'm going for ever or for a day to Brighton .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: You 're very hard .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Dick has been teaching me to take life flippantly . And I have learnt that things are only serious if you take them seriously , and that is desperately stupid .To LUCY .Do n't you agree with me ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No .

div.stage: Her tone , almost tragic , makes him pause for an instant ; but he is determined that the conversation shall be purely conventional .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: It 's so difficult to be serious without being absurd . That is the chief power of women , that life and death are merely occasions for a change of costume : marriage a creation in white , and the worship of God an opportunity for a Paris bonnet .

div.stage: MRS. CROWLEY makes up her mind to force a crisis , and she gets up .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: It 's growing late , Dick . Wo n't you take me round the house ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm afraid my luggage has made everything very disorderly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CROWLEY
sp.p: It does n't matter . Come , Dick !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: To LUCY .You do n't mind if we leave you ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , no .

div.stage: MRS. CROWLEY and DICK go out . There is a moment 's silence .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Do you know that our friend Dick has offered his hand and heart to Mrs. Crowley this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I hope they 'll be very happy . They 're very much in love with one another .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Bitterly .And is that a reason for marrying ? Surely love is the worst possible foundation for marriage . Love creates illusions , and marriages destroy them . True lovers should never marry .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Will you open the window ? It seems stifling here .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Certainly .From the window .You can n't think what a joy it is to look upon London for the last time . I 'm so thankful to get away .

div.stage: LUCY gives a little sob and ALEC turns to the window . He wants to wound her and yet cannot bear to see her suffer .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: To-morrow at this time I shall be well started . Oh , I long for that infinite surface of the clean and comfortable sea .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Are you very glad to go ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Turning to her .I feel quite boyish at the very thought .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And is there no one you regret to leave ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You see , Dick is going to marry . When a man does that , his bachelor friends are wise to depart gracefully before he shows them that he needs their company no longer . I have no relations and few friends . I can n't flatter myself that any one will be much distressed at my departure .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: In a low voice .You must have no heart at all .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Icily .If I had , I certainly should not bring it to Portman Square . That sentimental organ would be surely out of place in such a neighbourhood .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Gets up and goes to him .Oh , why do you treat me as if we were strangers ? How can you be so cruel ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Gravely .Do n't you think that flippancy is the best refuge from an uncomfortable position . We should really be much wiser merely to discuss the weather .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Insisting .Are you angry because I came ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: That would be ungracious on my part . Perhaps it was n't quite necessary that we should meet again .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You 've been acting all the time I 've been here . D'you think I did n't see it was unreal when you talked with such cynical indifference . I know you well enough to tell when you 're hiding your real self behind a mask .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: If I 'm doing that , the inference is obvious that I wish my real self to be hidden .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I would rather you cursed me than treat me with such cold politeness .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 're rather difficult to please .

div.stage: LUCY goes up to him passionately , but he draws back so that she may not touch him .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , you 're of iron . Alec , Alec , I could n't let you go without seeing you once more . Even you would be satisfied if you knew what bitter anguish I 've suffered . Even you would pity me . I do n't want you to think too badly of me .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Does it much matter what I think ? We shall be so many thousand miles apart .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I suppose that you utterly despise me .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No . I loved you far too much ever to do that . Believe me , I only wish you well . Now that the bitterness is past , I see that you did the only possible thing . I hope that you 'll be very happy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , Alec , do n't be utterly pitiless . Do n't leave me without a single word of kindness .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Nothing is changed , Lucy . You sent me away on account of your brother 's death .

div.stage: There is a long silence , and when she speaks it is hesitatingly , as if the words were painful to utter .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I hated you then , and yet I could n't crush the love that was in my heart . I used to try and drive you away from my thoughts , but every word you had ever said came back to me . Do n't you remember ? You told me that everything you did was for my sake . Those words hammered at my heart as though it were an anvil . I struggled not to believe them . I said to myself that you had sacrificed George coldly , callously , prudently , but in my heart I knew it was n't true .He looks at her , hardly able to believe what she is going to say , but does not speak .Your whole life stood on one side and only this hateful story on the other . You could n't have grown into a different man in one single instant . I came here to-day to tell you that I do n't understand the reason of what you did . I do n't want to understand . I believe in you now with all my strength . I know that whatever you did was right and just — because you did it .

div.stage: He gives a long , deep sigh .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Thank God ! Oh , I 'm so grateful to you for that .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Have n't you anything more to say to me than that ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You see , it comes too late . Nothing much matters now , for to-morrow I go away .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But you 'll come back .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I 'm going to a part of Africa from which Europeans seldom return .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: With a sudden outburst of passion .Oh , that 's too horrible . Do n't go , dearest ! I can n't bear it !

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: I must now . Everything is settled , and there can be no drawing back .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Do n't you care for me any more ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Care for you ? I love you with all my heart and soul .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Eagerly .Then take me with you .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: You !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You do n't know what I can do . With you to help me I can be brave . Let me come , Alec ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: No , it 's impossible . You do n't know what you ask .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Then let me wait for you ? Let me wait till you come back ?

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: And if I never come back ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I will wait for you still .

sp.speaker: ALEC
sp.p: Then have no fear . I will come back . My journey was only dangerous because I wanted to die . I want to live now , and I shall live .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , Alec , Alec , I 'm so glad you love me .

sp.speaker: TO
sp.p: GERALD KELLY “ Ich uebersah meine Sache und wusste wohin ich wollte . ” ECKERMANN , Gespraeche mit Goethe . GENERAL PREFACE ... For Clisthenes , son of Aristonymus , son of Myron , son of Andreas , had a daughter whose name was Agarista : her he resolved to give in marriage to the man whom he should find the most accomplished of all the Greeks . When therefore the Olympian games were being celebrated , Clisthenes , being victorious in them in the chariot race , made a proclamation ; “ that whoever of the Greeks deemed himself worthy to become the son-in-law of Clisthenes , should come to Sicyon on the sixtieth day , or even before ; since Clisthenes had determined on the marriage in a year , reckoning from the sixtieth day . ” Thereupon such of the Greeks as were puffed up with themselves and their country , came as suitors ; and Clisthenes , having made a race-course and palaestra for them , kept it for this very purpose . From Italy , accordingly , came Smindyrides , son of Hippocrates , a Sybarite , who more than any other man reached the highest pitch of luxury ,and Sybaris was at that time in a most flourishing condition ;and Damasus of Siris , son of Amyris called the Wise : these came from Italy . From the Ionian gulf , Amphimnestus , son of Epistrophus , an Epidamnian ; he came from the Ionian gulf . An AEtolian came , Males , brother of that Titormus who surpassed the Greeks in strength , and fled from the society of men to the extremity of the AEtolian territory . And from Peloponnesus , Leocedes , son of Pheidon , tyrant of the Argives , a decendant of that Pheidon , who introduced measures among the Peloponnesians , and was the most insolent of all the Greeks , who having removed the Elean umpires , himself regulated the games at Olympia ; his son accordingly came . And Amiantus , son of Lycurgus , an Arcadian from Trapezus ; and an Azenian from the city of Paeos , Laphanes , son of Euphorion , who , as the story is told in Arcadia , received the Dioscuri in his house , and after that entertained all men ; and an Elean , Onomastus , son of Agaeus : these accordingly came from the Peloponnesus itself . From Athens there came Megacles , son of Alcmaeon , the same who had visited Croesus , and another , Hippoclides , son of Tisander , who surpassed the Athenians in wealth and beauty . From Eretria , which was flourishing at that time , came Lysanias ; he was the only one from Euboea . And from Thessaly there came , of the Scopades , Diactorides a Cranonian ; and from the Molossi , Alcon . So many were the suitors . When they had arrived on the appointed day , Clisthenes made inquiries of their country , and the family of each ; then detaining them for a year , he made trial of their manly qualities , their dispositions , learning , and morals ; holding familiar intercourse with each separately , and with all together , and leading out to the gymnasia such of them as were younger ; but most of all he made trial of them at the banquet ; for as long as he detained them , he did this throughout , and at the same time entertained them magnificently . And somehow of all the suitors those that had come from Athens pleased him most , and of these Hippoclides , son of Tisander , was preferred both on account of his manly qualities , and because he was distantly related to the Cypselidae in Corinth . When the day appointed for the consummation of the marriage arrived , and for the declaration of Clisthenes himself , whom he would choose of them all , Clisthenes , having sacrificed a hundred oxen , entertained both the suitors themselves and all the Sicyonians ; and when they had concluded the feast , the suitors had a contest about music , and any subject proposed for conversation . As the drinking went on , Hippoclides , who much attracted the attention of the rest , ordered the flute-player to play a dance ; and when the flute-player obeyed , he began to dance : and he danced , probably so as to please himself ; but Clisthenes , seeing it , beheld the whole matter with suspicion . Afterwards , Hippoclides , having rested awhile , ordered some one to bring in a table ; and when the table came in , he first danced Laconian figures on it , and then Attic ones ; and in the third place , having leant his head on the table he gesticulated with his legs . But Clisthenes , when he danced the first and second time , revolted from the thought of having Hippoclides for his son-in-law , on account of his dancing and want of decorum , yet restrained himself , not wishing to burst out against him ; but when he saw him gesticulating with his legs , he was no longer able to restrain himself , and said : “ Son of Tisander , you have danced away your marriage . ” But Hippoclides answered : “ Hippoclides cares not . ” Hence this answer became a proverb .HERODOTUS VI . 126 , Cary 's Translation .This play was first performed by the Stage Society at the Imperial Theatre on February 22 , 1903 , with the following cast :

lg.l: JENNY BUSH WINIFRED FRASER
JAMES BUSH O . B. CLARENCE
JOHN HALLIWELL DENNIS EADIE
MABEL GERTRUDE BURNETT
HILDA MURRAY MABEL TERRY-LEWIS
ROBERT BRACKLEY NIGEL PLAYFAIR
MRS. GRIGGS HENRIETTA COWEN
FANNY GERTRUDE DE BURGH
BUTLER A. BOWYER
A MAN OF HONOUR
BASIL KENT
JENNY BUSH
JAMES BUSH
JOHN HALLIWELL
MABEL
HILDA MURRAY
ROBERT BRACKLEY
MRS. GRIGGS
FANNY
BUTLER
TIME : The Present Day .
ACT I — Basil 's lodgings in Bloomsbury .
ACTS II AND IV — The drawing-room of Basil 's house at Putney .

div.head: ACT III — Mrs. Murray 's house in Charles Street .

stage.stage: The Performing Rights of this Play are fully protected , and permission to perform it , whether by Amateurs or Professionals , must be obtained in advance from the author 's Sole Agent , R. Golding Bright , 20 Green Street , Leicester Square , London , W. C ., from whom all particulars can be obtained .

sp.speaker: THE FIRST ACT
sp.p: SITTING-ROOM OF BASIL 'S LODGINGS IN BLOOMSBURY . In the wall facing the auditorium , two windows with little iron balconies , giving a view of London roofs . Between the windows , against the wall , is a writing-desk littered with papers and books . On the right is a door , leading into the passage ; on the left a fire-place with arm-chairs on either side ; on the chimney-piece various smoking utensils . There are numerous bookshelves filled with books ; while on the walls are one or two Delft plates , etchings after Rossetti , autotypes of paintings by Fra Angelico and Botticelli . The furniture is simple and inexpensive , but there is nothing ugly in the room . It is the dwelling-place of a person who reads a great deal and takes pleasure in beautiful things . BASIL KENT is leaning back in his chair , with his feet on the writing-table , smoking a pipe and cutting the pages of a book . He is a very good-looking man of six-and-twenty , clean-shaven , with a delicate face and clear-cut features . He is dressed in a lounge-suit .

div.stage: There is a knock at the door .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Come in .

sp.speaker: MRS. GRIGGS
sp.p: Did you ring , sir ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes . I expect a lady to tea . And there 's a cake that I bought on my way in .

sp.speaker: MRS. GRIGGS
sp.p: Very well , sir .

div.stage: She goes out , and immediately comes in with a tray on which are two cups , sugar , milk , & c .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Griggs , I want to give up these rooms this day week . I 'm going to be married . I 'm sorry to leave you . You 've made me very comfortable .

sp.speaker: MRS. GRIGGS
sp.p: With a sigh of resignation .Ah , well , sir , that 's lodgers all over . If they 're gents they get married ; and if they 're ladies they ai n't respectable .

div.stage: A ring is heard .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: There 's the bell , Mrs. Griggs . I dare say it 's the lady I expect . If any one else comes , I 'm not at home .

sp.speaker: MRS. GRIGGS
sp.p: Very well , sir .

div.stage: She goes out , and BASIL occupies himself for a moment in putting things in order . MRS. GRIGGS , opening the door , ushers in the new-comers .

sp.speaker: MRS. GRIGGS
sp.p: If you please , sir .

div.stage: She goes out again , and during the next few speeches brings two more cups and the tea .

MABEL and HILDA enter , followed by JOHN HALLIWELL . BASIL going towards them very cordially , half stops when he notices who they are ; and a slight expression of embarrassment passes over his face . But he immediately recovers himself and is extremely gracious . HILDA MURRAY is a tall , handsome woman , self-possessed and admirably gowned . MABEL HALLIWELL is smaller , pretty rather than beautiful , younger than her sister , vivacious , very talkative , and somewhat irresponsible . JOHN is of the same age as BASIL , good-humoured , neither handsome nor plain blunt of speech and open .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shaking hands .How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Look pleased to see us , Mr. Kent .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 'm perfectly enchanted .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You did ask us to come and have tea with you , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 've asked you fifty times . Hulloa , John ! I did n't see you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'm the discreet husband , I keep in the background .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Why do n't you praise me instead of praising yourself ? People would think it so much nicer .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: On the contrary , they 'd be convinced that when we were alone I beat you . Besides , I could n't honestly say that you kept in the background .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: To BASIL .I feel rather ashamed at taking you unawares .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I was only slacking . I was cutting a book .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: That 's ever so much more fun than reading it , is n't it ?She catches sight of the tea things .Oh , what a beautiful cake — and two cups !She looks at him , questioning .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: A little awkwardly .Oh — I always have an extra cup in case some one turns up , you know .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: How unselfish ! And do you always have such expensive cake ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: With a smile , remonstrating .Mabel !

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Oh , but I know them well , and I love them dearly . They cost two shillings at the Army and Navy Stores , but I can n't afford them myself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wish you 'd explain why we 've come , or Basil will think I 'm responsible .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Lightly .I 've been trying to remember ever since we arrived . You say it , Hilda ; you invented it .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: With a laugh .Mabel , I 'll never take you out again . They 're perfectly incorrigible , Mr. Kent .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: To JOHN and MABEL , smiling .I do n't know why you 've come . Mrs. Murry has promised to come and have tea with me for ages .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Pretending to feel injured .Well , you need n't turn me out the moment we arrive . Besides , I refuse to go till I 've had a piece of that cake .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Well , here 's the tea !MRS. GRIGGS brings it in as he speaks . He turns to HILDA .I wish you 'd pour it out . I 'm so clumsy .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Smiling at him affectionately .I shall be delighted .

div.stage: She proceeds to do so , and the conversation goes on while BASIL hands MABEL tea and cake .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I told them it was improper for more than one woman at a time to call at a bachelor 's rooms , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: If you 'd warned me I 'd have made the show a bit tidier .

lg.l: Oh , that 's just what we did n't want . We wanted to see the Celebrity at
Home , without lime-light .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Ironically .You 're too flattering .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: By the way , how is the book ?

sp.speaker: Basil
sp.p: Quite well , thanks .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I always forget to ask how it 's getting on .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: On the contrary , you never let slip an opportunity of making kind inquiries .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I do n't believe you 've written a word of it .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Nonsense , Mabel . I 've read it .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Oh , but you 're such a monster of discretion .... Now I want to see your medals , Mr. Kent .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .What medals ?

lg.l: Do n't be coy ! You know I mean the medals they gave you for going to the
Cape .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Gets them from a drawer , and with a smile hands them to MABEL .If you really care to see them , here they are .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Taking one .What 's this ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , that 's just the common or garden South African medal .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: And the other one ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: That 's the D. S. M .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Why did n't they give you the D. S. O . ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I was only a trooper , you know . They only give the D. S. O . to officers .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: And what did you do to deserve it ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .I really forget .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: It 's given for distinguished service in the field , Mabel .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I knew . Only I wanted to see if Mr. Kent was modest or vain .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a smile , taking the medals from her and putting them away .How spiteful of you !

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: John , why did n't you go to the Cape , and do heroic things ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I confined my heroism to the British Isles . I married you , my angel .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Is that funny or vulgar ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Laughing .Are there no more questions you want to ask me , Mrs. Halliwell ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Yes , I want to know why you live up six flights of stairs .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Amused .For the view , simply and solely .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: But , good heavens , there is no view . There are only chimney-pots .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: But they 're most aesthetic chimney-pots . Do come and look , Mrs. Murray .BASIL and HILDA approach one of the windows , and he opens it .And at night they 're so mysterious . They look just like strange goblins playing on the house-tops . And you can n't think how gorgeous the sunsets are : sometimes , after the rain , the slate roofs glitter like burnished gold .To HILDA .Often I think I could n't have lived without my view , it says such wonderful things to me .Turning to MABEL gaily .Scoff , Mrs. Halliwell , I 'm on the verge of being sentimental .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I was wondering if you 'd made that up on the spur of the moment , or if you 'd fished it out of an old note-book .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: With a look at BASIL .May I go out ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes , do come .

div.stage: HILDA and BASIL step out on the balcony , whereupon JOHN goes to MABEL and tries to steal a kiss from her .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Springing up .Go away , you horror !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't be silly . I shall kiss you if I want to .

div.stage: She laughing , walks round the sofa while he pursues her .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I wish you 'd treat life more seriously .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wish you would n't wear such prominent hats .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: As he puts his arm round her waist .John , some body 'll see us .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mabel , I command you to let yourself be kissed .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: How much will you give me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sixpence .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Slipping away from him .I can n't do it for less than half-a-crown .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Laughing .I 'll give you two shillings .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Coaxing .Make it two-and-three .

div.stage: He kisses her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now come and sit down quietly .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Sitting down by his side .John , you must n't make love to me . It would look so odd if they came in .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: After all , I am your husband .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: That 's just it . If you wanted to make love to me you ought to have married somebody else .He puts his arm round her waist .John , do n't , I 'm sure they 'll come in .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't care if they do .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Sighing .John , you do love me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: And you wo n't ever care for anybody else ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: In the same tone .And you will give me that two-and-threepence , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mabel , it was only two shillings .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Oh , you cheat !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Getting up .I 'm going out on the balcony . I 'm passionately devoted to chimney-pots .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: No , John , I want you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Is n't it enough for me to say I want you for you to hurl yourself at my feet immediately ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , you poor thing , can n't you do without me for two minutes ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Now you 're taking a mean advantage . It 's only this particular two minutes that I want you . Come and sit by me like a nice , dear boy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now what have you been doing that you should n't ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Laughing .Nothing . But I want you to do something for me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ha , ha ! I thought so .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: It 's merely to tie up my shoe .She puts out her foot .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Is that all — honour bright ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Laughing .Yes .JOHN kneels down .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But , my good girl , it 's not undone .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Then , my good boy , undo it and do it up again .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Starting up .Mabel , are we playing gooseberry — at our time of life ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Ironically .Oh , you are clever ! Do you think Hilda would have climbed six flights of stairs unless Love had lent her wings ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wish Love would provide wings for the chaperons as well .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Do n't be flippant . It 's a serious matter .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My dear girl , you really can n't expect me to play the heavy father when we 've only been married six months . It would be almost improper .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Do n't be horrid , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It is n't horrid , it 's natural history .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Primly .I was never taught it . It 's not thought nice for young girls to know .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why did n't you tell me that Hilda was fond of Basil ! Does he like her ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I do n't know . I expect that 's precisely what she 's asking him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mabel , do you mean to say you brought me here , an inoffensive , harmless creature , for your sister to propose to a pal of mine ? It 's an outrage .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: She 's doing nothing of the sort .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You need n't look indignant . You can n't deny that you proposed to me .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I can , indeed . If I had I should never have taken such an unconscionably long time about it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wonder why Hilda wants to marry poor Basil !

lg.l: Well , Captain Murray left her five thousand a year , and she thinks Basil
Kent a genius .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: There 's not a drawing-room in Regent 's Park or in Bayswater that has n't got its tame genius . I do n't know if Basil Kent is much more than very clever .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Anyhow , I 'm sure it 's a mistake to marry geniuses . They 're horribly bad-tempered , and they invariably make love to other people 's wives .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Hilda always has gone in for literary people . That 's the worst of marrying a cavalryman , it leads you to attach so much importance to brains .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Yes , but she need n't marry them . If she wants to encourage Basil let her do it from a discreet distance . Genius always thrives best on bread and water and platonic attachments . If Hilda marries him he 'll only become fat and ugly and bald-headed and stupid .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why , then he 'll make an ideal Member of Parliament .

div.stage: BASIL and HILDA come into the room again .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Maliciously .Well , what have you been talking about ?

lg.l: The weather and the crops , Shakespeare and the Musical
Glasses .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Raising her eyebrows .Oh !

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: It 's getting very late , Mabel . We really must be going .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Getting up .And I 've got to pay at least twelve calls . I hope every one will be out .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: People are so stupid , they 're always in when you call .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Holding out her hand to BASIL .Good-bye .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Coldly .Thanks so much , Mr. Kent . I 'm afraid we disturbed you awfully .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shaking hands with her .I 've been enchanted to see you . Good-bye .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Lightly .We shall see you again before you go to Italy , sha n't we ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I 'm not going to Italy now , I 've changed all my plans .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Giving JOHN a look .Oh ! Well , good-bye . Are n't you coming , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No : I think I 'll stay and have a little chat with Basil , while you tread the path of duty .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Well , mind you 're in early . We 've got a lot of disgusting people coming to dinner .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: With a smile .Poor things ! Who are they ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I forget who they are . But I know they 're loathsome . That 's why I asked them .

div.stage: BASIL opens the door , and the two women go out .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sitting down and stretching himself .Now that we 've got rid of our womankind let 's make ourselves comfortable .Taking a pipe out of his pocket .I think I 'll sample your baccy if you 'll pass it along .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Handing him the jar .I 'm rather glad you stayed , John . I wanted to talk to you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ha ! ha !

div.stage: BASIL pauses a moment , while JOHN looks at him with amusement . He fills his pipe .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Lighting his pipe .Nice gal , Hilda — ai n't she ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Enthusiastically .Oh , I think she 's perfectly charming .... But what makes you say that ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Innocently .Oh , I do n't know . Passed through my head .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I say , I 've got something to tell you , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , do n't be so beastly solemn about it .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .It 's a solemn thing .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , it ai n't . I 've done it myself . It 's like a high dive . When you look down at the water it fairly takes your breath away , but after you 've done it — it 's not so bad as you think . You 're going to be married , my boy .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a smile .How the deuce d'you know ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gaily .Saw it with mine own eyes . I congratulate you , and I give you my blessing . I 'll get a new frock-coat to give the lady away in .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You ?...Suddenly understanding .You 're on the wrong tack , old man . It 's not your sister-in-law I 'm going to marry .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then why the dickens did you say it was ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I never mentioned her name .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: H 'm ! I 've made rather more than an average ass of myself , have n't I ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: What on earth made you think ...?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Interrupting .Oh , it was only some stupid idea of my wife 's . Women are such fools , you know . And they think they 're so confoundedly sharp .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Disconcerted — looking at him .Has Mrs. Murray ...?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , of course not ! Well , who the deuce are you going to marry ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Flushing .I 'm going to marry Miss Jenny Bush .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Never heard of her . Is it any one I know ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes , you knew her .

lg.l: Bush ... Bush ....
The only
Jenny Bush I 've ever heard of was a rather pretty little barmaid in
Fleet Street . Presumably you 're not going to marry her .

div.stage: JOHN has said this quite lightly , not guessing for a moment that it can have anything to do with the person BASIL proposes to marry . Then , since BASIL makes no answer , JOHN looks at him sharply : there is a silence while the two men stare at one another .

lg.l: Basil , it 's not the woman we used to know before you went out to the
Cape ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Pale and nervous , but determined .I 've just told you that you used to know Jenny .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Man alive , you 're not going to marry the barmaid of the “ Golden Crown ” ?

lg.l: Jenny was a barmaid at the “ Golden
Crown . ”

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But , good Lord , Basil , what d'you mean ? You 're not serious ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Perfectly ! We 're going to be married this day week .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Are you stark , staring mad ? Why on earth d'you want to marry Jenny Bush ?

lg.l: That 's rather a delicate question , is n't it ?
Presumably because I 'm in love with her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , that 's a silly ass of an answer .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It 's quite the most obvious .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nonsense ! Why , I 've been in love with twenty girls , and I have n't married them all . One can n't do that sort of thing in a country where they give you seven years for bigamy . Every public-house along the Thames from Barnes to Taplow is the tombstone of an unrequited passion of my youth . I loved ‘ em dearly , but I never asked ‘ em to marry me .

lg.l: I 'd rather you did n't make jokes about it ,
John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Are you sure you 're not making an ass of yourself ? If you 've got into a mess , surely we can get you out . Marriage , like hanging , is rather a desperate remedy .

div.stage: BASIL is sitting down and moodily shrugs his shoulders . JOHN goes up to him , and putting his hands on his friend 's shoulders looks into his eyes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why are you going to marry her , Basil ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Springing up impatiently .Damn you , why do n't you mind your own business ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't be a fool , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Ca n't I marry any one I choose ? It 's nothing to you , is it ? D'you suppose I care if she 's a barmaid ?

div.stage: He walks up and down excitedly , while JOHN with steady eyes watches him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Basil , old man , we 've known each other a good many years now . Do n't you think you 'd better trust me ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Setting his teeth .What d'you want to know ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why are you going to marry her ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Abruptly , fiercely .Because I must .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nodding his head quietly .I see .

div.stage: There is a silence . Then BASIL , more calmly turns to JOHN .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: D'you remember Jenny ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , rather . Why , we always lunched there in the old days .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Well , after I came back from the Cape I began going there again . When I was out there she took it into her head to write me a letter , rather ill-spelt and funny — but I was touched that she thought of me . And she sent some tobacco and some cigarettes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My maiden aunt sent you a woollen comforter , but I 'm not aware that in return you ever made her a proposal of marriage .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: And so in one way and another I came to know Jenny rather well . She appeared to get rather fond of me — and I could n't help seeing it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But she always pretended to be engaged to that scrubby little chap with false teeth who used to hang about the bar and make sheep 's eyes at her over innumerable Scotch-and-sodas .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: He made a scene because I took her out on one of her off-nights , and she broke it off . I could n't help knowing it was on my account .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , and after that ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: After that I got into the habit of taking her to the play , and so on . And finally ...!

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How long has this been going on ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Several months .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And then ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Well , the other day she wired for me . I found her in the most awful state . She was simply crying her eyes out , poor thing . She 'd been seedy and gone to the doctor 's . And he told her ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What you might really have foreseen .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes .... She was quite hysterical . She said she did n't know what to do nor where to go . And she was in an awful funk about her people . She said she 'd kill herself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Drily .Naturally she was very much upset .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I felt the only thing I could do was to ask her to marry me . And when I saw the joy that came into her poor , tear-stained face I knew I 'd done the right thing .

div.stage: There is a pause . JOHN walks up and down , then stops suddenly and turns to BASIL .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Have you thought that you , who 've never needed to economise , will have to look at every shilling you spend ? You 've always been careless with your money , and what you 've had you 've flung about freely .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .If I have to submit to nothing worse than going without a lot of useless luxuries , I really do n't think I need complain .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But you can n't afford to keep a wife and an increasing family .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I suppose I can make money as well as other men .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: By writing books ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I shall set to work to earn my living at the Bar . Up till now I 've never troubled myself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't know any man less fit than you for the dreary waiting and the drudgery of the Bar .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: We shall see .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And what d'you think your friends will say to your marrying — a barmaid ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Contemptuously .I do n't care two straws for my friends .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That 's pleasant for them . You know , men and women without end have snapped their fingers at society and laughed at it , and for a while thought they had the better of it . But all the time society was quietly smiling up its sleeve , and suddenly it put out an iron hand — and scrunched them up .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .It only means that a few snobs will cut me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Not you — your wife .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 'm not such a cad as to go to a house where I can n't take my wife .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But you 're the last man in the world to give up these things . There 's nothing you enjoy more than going to dinner-parties and staying in country houses . Women 's smiles are the very breath of your nostrils .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You talk of me as if I were a tame cat . I do n't want to brag , John , but after all , I 've shown that I 'm fit for something in this world . I went to the Cape because I thought it was my duty . I intend to marry Jenny for the same reason .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Seriously .Will you answer me one question — on your honour ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Are you in love with her ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: After a pause .No .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Passionately .Then , by God , you have no right to marry her . A man has no right to marry a woman for pity . It 's a cruel thing to do . You can only end by making yourself and her entirely wretched .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I can n't break the poor girl 's heart .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You do n't know what marriage is . Even with two people who are devoted to one another , who have the same interests and belong to the same class , it 's sometimes almost unbearable . Marriage is the most terrible thing in the world unless passion makes it absolutely inevitable .

sp.speaker: BASIL
