sp.p: My marriage is absolutely inevitable — for another reason .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You talk as if such things had never happened before .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I know , they happen every day . It 's no business of the man 's . And as for the girl , let her throw herself in the river . Let her go to the deuce , and be hanged to her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nonsense . She can be provided for . It only needs a little discretion — and no one will be a ha'porth the wiser , nor she a ha'porth the worse .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: But it 's not a matter of people knowing . It 's a matter of honour .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Opening his eyes .And where precisely did the honour come in when you ...?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Good heavens , I 'm a man like any other . I have passions as other men have .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gravely .My dear Basil , I would n't venture to judge you . But I think it 's rather late in the day to set up for a moralist .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: D'you think I 've not regretted what I did ? It 's easy enough afterwards to say that I should have resisted . The world would be a Sunday School if we were all as level-headed at night as we are next morning .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Shaking his head .After all , it 's only a very regrettable incident due to your youth and — want of innocence .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With vehement seriousness .I may have acted like a cur . I do n't know . I acted as I suppose every other man would . But now I have a plain duty before me , and , by God , I mean to do it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't you realise that you 've only one life and that mistakes are irreparable ? People play with life as if it were a game of chess in which they can try this move and that , and when they get into a muddle , sweep the board clear and begin again .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: But life is a game of chess in which one is always beaten . Death sits on the other side of the board , and for every move he has a counter-move . And for all your deep-laid schemes he has a parry .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But if at the end Death always mates you , the fight is surely worth the fighting . Do n't handicap yourself at the beginning by foolish quixotry . Life is so full . It has so much to offer , and you 're throwing away almost everything that makes it worth the trouble .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Gravely .Jenny would kill herself if I did n't marry her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You do n't seriously think she 'd do that . People do n't commit suicide so easily , you know .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You 've thought of a great deal , John — you 've not thought of the child . I can n't let the child skulk into the world like a thief . Let him come in openly and lawfully . And let him go through the world with an honest name . Good heavens , the world 's bad enough without fettering him all his life with a hideous stigma .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , my dear Basil ...

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Interrupting .You can bring forward a thousand objections , but nothing alters the fact that , under the circumstances , there 's only one way open to a man of honour .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Drily .Well , it 's a way that may do credit to your heart , but scarcely to your understanding .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I thought you 'd see at once that I was doing the only possible thing .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My dear Basil , you talk of pity , and you talk of duty , but are you sure there 's anything more in it than vanity ? You 've set yourself up on a sort of moral pinnacle . Are you sure you do n't admire your own heroism a little too much ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a good-natured smile .Does it look so petty as that in your eyes ? After all , it 's only common morality .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Impatiently .But , my dear chap , its absurd to act according to an unrealisable ideal in a world that 's satisfied with the second-rate . You 're tendering bank-notes to African savages , among whom cowrie shells are common coin .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .I do n't know what you mean .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Society has made its own decalogue , a code that 's just fit for middling people who are not very good and not very wicked . But Society punishes you equally if your actions are higher than its ideal or lower .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Sometimes it makes a god of you when you 're dead .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But it takes precious good care to crucify you when you 're alive .

div.stage: There is a knock at the door , and MRS. GRIGGS comes in .

sp.speaker: MRS. GRIGGS
sp.p: Some more visitors , Sir .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Show ‘ em in .To JOHNIt 's Jenny . She said she was coming to tea .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a smile .Oh , the cake was for her , was it ? Would you like me to go ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Not unless you choose . Do you suppose I 'm ashamed ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I thought , after all you 've told me , you might not care for me to see her .

div.stage: JENNY BUSH and her brother JAMES come in . She is very pretty , with delicate features and a beautiful complexion : her fair hair is abundant and very elaborately arranged . She is dressed smartly , rather showily . It is the usual type of barmaid , or tea-girl , a shade more refined perhaps than the common run . Her manners are unobjectionable , but not those of a gentlewoman . JAMES is a young man with clean-shaven face and a sharp expression . He is over-dressed in a very horsey manner , and is distinctly more vulgar than his sister . He talks English with a cockney accent , not invariably dropping his aitches , but only now and then . He is over cordial and over genial .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Going up to BASIL .I 'm awfully late , I could n't come before .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Jocosely .Do n't mind me . Give ‘ im a kiss , old tart .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , I brought my brother Jimmie to see you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shaking hands .How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Nicely , thanks . Pleased to make your acquaintance .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Looking at JOHN and suddenly recognising him .Well , I never ! If that is n't old John Halliwell . I did n't expect to see you . This is a treat .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: What are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 've been having a cup of tea with Basil .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Looking at the tea-things .D'you always drink out of three cups at once ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My wife has been here — and her sister .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , I see . Fancy your being married . How d'you like it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right , thanks .

div.stage: BASIL pours out a cup of tea , and during the following speeches gives JENNY milk and sugar and cake .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: People say it wants a bit of gettin ’ used to .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mr. Bush , you 're a philosopher .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , I will say this for myself , you 'd want to get up early in the morning to catch me nappin ’ . I did n't catch your name .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Halliwell .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: ‘ Alliwell ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Emphasising the H .Halliwell .

lg.l: That 's what I say — ‘ Alliwell . I knew a fellow in the meat trade called
‘ Alliwell . Any relation ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Fine business ‘ e ‘ ad too . There 's a rare lot of money to be made out of meat .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I dare say .

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: To JOHN .It is a long time since I 've seen you . I suppose you 've quietened down now you 're a married man . You were a hot ‘ un when you was a bachelor .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Facetiously .Do n't make ‘ im blush , Jenny . Accidents will ‘ appen in the best regulated families . And boys will be boys , as they say in the Bible .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I think I must be off , Basil .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , I 'll be toddlin ’ too . I only come in just to say ‘ ow d'you do to my future brother-in-law . I 'm a fellow as likes to be cordial . There 's no ‘ aughtiness about me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Politely , but not effusively .Oh ; wo n't you stay and have some tea ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , thanks . I 'm not much of an ‘ and at tea ; I leave that to females . I like something stronger myself .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Remonstrating .Jimmie !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I have some whisky , Mr. Bush .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh , blow the Mister and blow the Bush . Call me Jimmie . I can n't stand ceremony . The way I look on it is this . We 're both of us gentlemen . Now , mind you , I 'm not a fellow to praise myself . But I will say this : I am a gentleman . That 's not self-praise , is it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Dear me , no . Mere statement of fact .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , as I was saying , I know I 'm a gentleman . It 's a thing you can n't ‘ elp , so what 's the good of being proud about it ? If I meet a chap in a pub , and he invites me to have a drink , I do n't ask him if he 's a Lord .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: But you just take it .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , you 'd do the same yourself , would n't you ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I dare say . But will you have a drink now ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh , bless you , I know what it is to be engaged . I do n't want to disturb you canary-birds . Me and ‘ Alliwell ‘ ll go and have a gargle round the corner . I see you 've got a public nice and ‘ andy .To JOHN .I suppose you 're not above goin ’ in there now and again , eh ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With a laugh .He came into the “ Golden Crown ” every day of his life , and chance it !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm in a great hurry .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: ‘ Ang it all , one 's always got time to have a drop of Scotch in this life .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: To JAMES , handing him the box .Well , take a cigar with you .

lg.l: If you are so pressing . Villar y
Villar .... What do they run you in a hundred ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: They were given to me , I really do n't know what they cost .He lights a match .Wo n't you take the label off ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Not if I know it . I do n't smoke a Villar y Villar every day , but when I do , I smoke it with the label on .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Laughing .Jimmie , you are a caution !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Shaking hands with JENNY .Good-bye and — my best wishes .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Thanks . You did n't expect I 'd marry Basil when I used to mix cocktails for you in the “ Golden Crown , ” did you ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Come on , ‘ Alliwell . Do n't stop there gassing . You 'll only disturb the canary-birds . So long , old tart , see you later . Ta-ta , Basil , old man .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Good-bye — Jimmie .

div.stage: JOHN HALLIWELL and JAMES go out , JENNY goes up to BASIL impulsively .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Kiss me .He kisses her , smiling .There ! Now I can sit down quietly and talk . How d'you like my brother ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh — I hardly know him yet . He seems very amiable .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: He 's not a bad sort when you know him . He 's just like my mother .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Raising his brows .Is he ? And — is your father like that too ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Well , you know , Pa has n't had the education that Jimmie 's had . Jimmie was at a boarding-school at Margate .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Was he ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You were at a boarding-school , too , were n't you ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .Yes , I was at Harrow .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Ah , you do n't get the fine air at Harrow that you get at Margate .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shall I put down your cup ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Placing it on a table .Oh , thanks , it 's all right . Come and sit by me , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Seating himself on the arm of her chair .There .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Taking his hand .I 'm so glad we 're alone . I should like to be alone with you all my life . You do love me , do n't you , Basil ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Much ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .Yes .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I 'm so glad . Oh , I do n't know what I should do if you did n't love me . If you had n't been kind to me I should have thrown myself in the river .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: What nonsense you talk .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I mean it .

div.stage: He passes his hand affectionately over her hair .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , you are so good , Basil . I 'm so proud of you . I shall be so proud to be your wife .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Gravely .Do n't think too well of me Jenny .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With a laugh .I 'm not afraid of that . You 're brave and you 're clever and you 're a professional man , and you 're everything .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You foolish child .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Passionately .I can n't tell you how much I love you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 'll try with all my might to be a good husband to you , Jenny .

div.stage: She flings her arms round his neck and they kiss one another .
END OF THE FIRST ACT .

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

sp.speaker: AN INTERVAL OF ONE YEAR ELAPSES BETWEEN ACTS I . AND II
sp.p: The drawing-room in Basil 's house at Putney . In the wall facing the auditorium there is a door leading from the passage . On the right two doors lead into bedrooms , and opposite these is a bay window . The same pictures and plates decorate the walls as in the preceding Scene ; the writing-table is between the side doors . JENNY 'S influence is noticeable in the cushions in the wicker-work arm-chairs , in the window curtains and portieres of art serge , and in the huge chrysanthemums of the wall paper .

div.stage: JENNY is sewing while JAMES BUSH is lounging in one of the arm chairs .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Where 's his lordship this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: He 's gone out for a walk .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: With a malevolent laugh .That 's what he tells you , my dear .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Looking up quickly .Have you seen him anywhere ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , I can n't say I ‘ ave. And if I ‘ ad I would n't boast about it .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Insisting .What did you mean then ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , whenever I come here he 's out for a walk .... I say , old tart , could you oblige me with a couple of sovereigns till next Saturday ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Pained to refuse .Oh no , Jimmie , I can n't manage it . Basil made me promise I would n't let you have any more .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: What ! He made you promise that ?— Ugh , the mean skinflint .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: We 've lent you so much , Jimmie . And ma 's had a lot , too .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , look here , you can manage a sovereign , can n't you ? You need n't say anything about it .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I can n't really , Jimmie . I would if I could . But we 've got a rare lot of debts worrying us , and the rent will be coming along next week .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Sulkily .You can n't lend it me because you wo n't . I should just like to know what Basil spends his money on .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: He 's had a bad year — it 's not his fault . And I was so ill after the baby died , we had to pay the doctor nearly fifty pounds .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: With a sneer .Well , it was a wonderful fine thing you did when you married him , Jenny . And you thought you done precious well for yourself , too .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Jimmie , do n't !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I can n't stick ‘ im at any price , and I do n't mind who knows it .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Impetuously .I wo n't have you say anything against him .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: All right — keep your shirt in . I 'm blowed if I know what you 've got to stick up for him about . He do n't care much about you .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Hastily .How d'you know ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Think I can n't see !

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: It 's not true . It 's not true .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You can n't get round me , Jenny . I suppose you ‘ ave n't been crying to-day ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Flushing .I had a headache .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I know those sort of headaches .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: We had a little tiff this morning . That 's why he went out .... Oh , do n't say he does n't care for me . I could n't live .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: With a laugh .Go along with you . Basil Kent ai n't the only pebble on the beach .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Vehemently .Oh , Jimmie , Jimmie , sometimes I do n't know which way to turn , I 'm that unhappy . If the baby had only lived I might have kept my husband — I might have made him love me .The sound is heard of a door being closed .There 's Basil .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Good luck to ‘ im .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , Jimmie , take care not to say anything to make him angry .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'd just like to give ‘ im a piece of my mind .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , Jimmie , do n't . It was my fault that we quarrelled this morning . I wanted to make him angry , and I nagged at him . Do n't let him see that I 've said anything to you . I 'll see — I 'll see if I can n't send you a pound to-morrow , Jimmie .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Defiantly .He 'd better not start patronising me , because I wo n't put up with it . I 'm a gentleman , and I 'm every bit as good as he is — if not better .

div.stage: BASIL comes in , notices JAMES , but does not speak .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Afternoon , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Indifferently .You here again ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Looks like it , do n't it .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Quietly .I 'm afraid it does .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Becoming more aggressive as the conversation proceeds .Are you ? I suppose I can come and see my own sister ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I suppose it 's inevitable .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .Only I should be excessively grateful if you 'd time your coming with my — with my going . And vice versa .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: That means you want me to get out , I reckon .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You show unusual perspicacity , dear James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: And who are you with your long words , I should like to know ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Blandly .I ? A person of not the least importance .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Angrily .Well , I would n't put on so much side if I was you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I observe that you have not acquired the useful art of being uncivil without being impertinent .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Look ‘ ere , I 'm not going to stand this . I 'm as good as you are any day .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: That is a fact I should never dream of contradicting .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Indignantly .Then what ‘ ave you got to turn up your nose about , eh ? What d'you mean by sneerin ’ and snarlin ’ at me when I come here ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Nervously .Jimmie , do n't !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a smile .You 're very eloquent , James . You should join a debating society .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , go on . That 's right . You seem to think I 'm nobody . I should just like to know why you go on as if I was I do n't know what .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Abruptly .Because I choose .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You can bet anything you like I do n't come ‘ ere to see you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling acidly .Then I have at least something to be thankful for .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 've got a right to come here as much as anybody . I come to see my sister .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Really , that 's very thoughtful of you . I was under the impression you generally came to borrow money .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Throw that in my face now . I can n't ‘ elp it if I 'm out of work .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I have n't the least objection to your being out of work . All I protest against — and that very mildly — is that I should be expected to keep you . How much did you want to-day ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't want your dirty money .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a laugh .Have you already tried to borrow it from Jenny ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , I ‘ ave n't .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: And she refused , I suppose .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Storming .I tell you I do n't want your dirty money .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Well , then , we 're both quite satisfied . You seemed to think that because I married Jenny I was bound to keep the whole gang of you for the rest of your lives . I 'm sorry I can n't afford it . And you will kindly tell the rest of them that I 'm sick and tired of forking out .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I wonder you do n't forbid me your house while you 're about it .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Coolly .You may come here when I 'm not at home — if you behave yourself .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'm not good enough for you , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: No , you 're not .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Angrily .Ah , you 're a pretty specimen , you are . You mean skinflint !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Do n't be abusive , James . It 's rude .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I shall say what I choose .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: And please do n't talk so loud . It annoys me .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Malevolently .I dare say you 'd like to get me out of the way . But I mean to keep my eye on you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Sharply .What d'you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You know what I mean . Jenny has something to put up with , I lay .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Containing his anger .You 'll have the goodness to leave the relations between Jenny and myself alone — d'you hear ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Ha , that 's touched you up , has it ? You think I do n't know what sort of a feller you are . I can just about see through two of you . And I know a good deal more about you than you think .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Contemptuously .Do n't be foolish , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Sarcastic .A nice thing Jenny did when she married you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Recovering himself , with a smile .Has she been telling you my numerous faults ?To JENNY .You must have had plenty to talk about , my love .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Who has been going on with her sewing , looking up now and then uneasily .I have n't said a word against you , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Turning his back on JAMES .Oh , my dear Jenny , if it amuses you , by all means discuss me with your brother and your sister and your father and your mother , and the whole crew of them .... I should be so dull if I had no faults .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Anxiously .Tell him I 've not said anything against him , Jimmie .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: It 's not for want of something to say , I lay .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Over his shoulder .I 'm getting rather tired , brother James . I 'd go , if I were you .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Very aggressively .I sha n't go till I choose .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Turns round , smiling blandly .Of course , we 're both Christians , dear James ; and there 's a good deal of civilisation kicking about the world nowadays . But , notwithstanding , the last word is still with the strongest .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: What d'you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Merely that discretion is the better part of valour . They say that proverbs are the wealth of nations .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Indignantly .That 's just the sort of thing you 'd do — to ‘ it a feller smaller than yourself .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I would n't hit you for worlds , brother James . I should merely throw you downstairs .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Making for the door .I should just like to see you try it on .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Do n't be silly , James . You know you would n't like it at all .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'm not afraid of you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Of course not . But still — you 're not very muscular , are you ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You coward !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .Your repartees are not brilliant , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Standing at the door for safety 's sake .I 'll pay you out before I 've done .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Raising his eyebrows .James , I told you to get out five minutes ago .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'm going . D'you think I want to stay ‘ ere ? Good-bye , Jenny , I 'm not going to stand being insulted by any one .He goes out slamming the door .

div.stage: BASIL , smiling quietly , goes to his writing-table and turns over some papers .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: The only compensation in brother James is that he sometimes causes one a little mild amusement .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You might at least be polite to him , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I used up all my politeness six months ago .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: After all , he is my brother .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: That is a fact I deplore with all my heart , I assure you .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I do n't know what 's wrong with him .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Do n't you ? It does n't matter .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I know he is n't a Society man .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a laugh .No , he would n't shine at duchesses tea-parties .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Well , he 's none the worse for that , is he ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Then why d'you treat him as if he was a dog ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: My dear Jenny , I do n't .... I 'm very fond of dogs .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , you 're always sneering . Is n't he as good as I am ? And you condescended to marry me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Coldly .I really can n't see that because I married you I must necessarily take your whole family to my bosom .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Why do n't you like them ? They 're honest and respectable .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a little sigh of boredom .My dear Jenny , we do n't choose our friends because they 're honest and respectable any more than we choose them because they change their linen daily .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: They can n't help it if they 're poor .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: My dear , I 'm willing to acknowledge that they have every grace and every virtue , but they rather bore me .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: They would n't if they were swells .

div.stage: BASIL gives a short laugh , but does not answer ; and JENNY irritated , continues more angrily .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: And after all we 're not in such a bad position as all that . My mother 's father was a gentleman .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I wish your mother 's son were .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: D'you know what Jimmie says you are ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I do n't vastly care . But if it pleases you very much you may tell me .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Flushing angrily .He says you 're a damned snob .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Is that all ? I could have invented far worse things than that to say of myself ....With a change of tone .You know , Jenny , it 's not worth while to worry ourselves about such trifles . One can n't force oneself to like people . I 'm very sorry that I can n't stand your relations . Why on earth do n't you resign yourself and make the best of it ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Vindictively .You do n't think they 're good enough for you to associate with because they 're not in swell positions .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: My dear Jenny , I do n't in the least object to their being grocers and haberdashers . I only wish they 'd sell us things at cost price .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Jimmie is n't a grocer or a haberdasher . He 's an auctioneer 's clerk .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Ironically .I humbly apologise . I thought he was a grocer , because last time he did us the honour of visiting us he asked how much a pound we paid for our tea and offered to sell us some at the same price .... But then he also offered to insure our house against fire and to sell me a gold mine in Australia .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Well , it 's better to make a bit as best one can than to ....She stops .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Smiling .Go on . Pray do n't hesitate for fear of hurting my feelings .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Defiantly .Well , then , it 's better to do that than moon about like you do .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .Really , even to please you , I 'm afraid I can n't go about with little samples of tea in my pocket and sell my friends a pound or two when I call on them . Besides , I do n't believe they 'd ever pay me .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Scornfully .Oh no , you 're a gentleman and a barrister and an author , and you could n't do anything to dirty those white hands that you 're so careful about , could you ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Looking at his hands , then up at JENNY .And what is it precisely you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Well , you 've been at the Bar for five years . I should have thought you could make something after all that time .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I can n't force the wily solicitor to give me briefs .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: How do other fellows manage it ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a laugh .The simplest way , I believe , is to marry the wily solicitor 's daughter .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Instead of a barmaid ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Gravely .I did n't say that , Jenny .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Passionately .Oh no . You did n't say it , but you hinted it . You never say anything , but you 're always hinting and insinuating — till you drive me out of my senses .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: After a moment 's pause , gravely .I 'm very sorry if I hurt your feelings . I promise you I do n't mean to . I always try to be kind to you .

div.stage: He looks at JENNY , expecting her to say something in forgiveness or in apology . But she , shrugging her shoulders , looks down sullenly at her work , without a word , and begins again to sew . Then BASIL , tightening his lips , picks up writing materials and goes towards the door .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Looking up quickly .Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Stopping .I have some letters to write .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Ca n't you write them here ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Certainly — if it pleases you .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Do n't you want me to see who you 're writing to ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I have n't the least objection to your knowing all about my correspondence .... And that 's fortunate , since you invariably make yourself acquainted with it .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Accuse me of reading your letters now .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a smile .You always leave my papers in such disorder after you 've been to my desk .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You 've got no right to say that .

div.stage: BASIL pauses and looks at her steadily .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Are you willing to swear that you do n't go to my desk when I 'm away to read my letters ? Come , Jenny , answer that question .

lg.stage: Disturbed but forced by his glance to reply .
lg.l: Well , I 'm you 're wife ,
I have a right to know .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Bitterly .You have such odd ideas about the duties of a wife , Jenny . They include reading my letters and following me in the street . But tolerance and charity and forbearance do n't seem to come in your scheme of things .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Sullenly .Why d'you want to write your letters elsewhere ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .I thought I should be quieter .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I suppose I disturb you ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It 's a little difficult to write when you 're talking .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Why should n't I talk ? D'you think I 'm not good enough , eh ? I should have thought I was more important than your letters .

div.stage: BASIL does not answer .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Angrily .Am I your wife or not ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Ironically .You have your marriage lines carefully locked up to prove it .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Then why do n't you treat me as your wife ? You seem to think I 'm only fit to see after the house and order the dinner and mend your clothes . And after that I can go and sit in the kitchen with the servant .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Moving again towards the door .D'you think it 's worth while making a scene ? We seem to have said all this before so many times .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Interrupting him .I want to have it out .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Bored .We 've been having it out twice a week for the last six months — and we 've never got anywhere yet .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I 'm not going to be always put upon , I 'm your wife and I 'm as good as you are .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a thin smile .Oh , my dear , if you 're going in for women 's rights , you may have my vote by all means . And you can plump for all the candidates at once if you choose .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You seem to think it 's a joke .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Bitterly .Oh no , I promise you I do n't do that . It 's lasted too long . And God knows where it 'll end .... They say the first year of marriage is the worst ; ours has been bad enough in all conscience .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Aggressively .And I suppose you think it 's my fault ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Do n't you think we 're both more or less to blame ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With a laugh .Oh , I 'm glad you acknowledge that you have something to do with it .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I tried to make you happy .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Well , you have n't succeeded very well . Did you think I was likely to be happy — when you leave me alone all day and half the night for your swell friends that I 'm not good enough for ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: That 's not true . I hardly ever see any of my old friends .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Except Mrs. Murray , eh ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 've seen Mrs. Murray perhaps a dozen times in the last year .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , you need n't tell me that . I know it . She 's a lady , is n't she ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Ignoring the charge .And my work takes me away from you . I can n't always be down here . Think how bored you 'd be .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: A precious lot of good your work does . You can n't earn enough money to keep us out of debt .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Good-humouredly .We are in debt . But we share that very respectable condition with half the nobility and gentry in the kingdom . We 're neither of us good managers , and we 've lived a bit beyond our means this year . But in future we 'll be more economical .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Sullenly .All the neighbours know that we 've got bills with the tradesmen .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Acidly .I 'm sorry that you should n't have made so good a bargain as you expected when you married me .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I wonder what you do succeed in ? Your book was very successful , was n't it ? You thought you were going to set the Thames on fire , and the book fell flat , flat , flat .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Recovering his good temper .That is a fate which has befallen better books than mine .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: It deserved it .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I did n't expect you to appreciate it . It is n't given to all of us to write about wicked earls and beautiful duchesses .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Well , I was n't the only one . The papers praised it , did n't they ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: The unanimity of their blame was the only thing that consoled me .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: And one of them advised you to study an English grammar . And you 're the fine gentleman who looks down on poor things like us !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I often wonder if the reviewer who abuses you for a printer 's error realises what pleasure he causes the wife of your bosom .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , I 've learnt to know you so well this last six months — since the baby died . You 've got no cause to set yourself up on a pedestal .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a laugh .My dear Jenny , I never pretended to be a golden idol .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I know what you are now . And I was such a fool as to think you a hero . You 're merely a failure . In everything you try you 're a miserable failure .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a slight sigh .Perhaps you 're right , Jenny .

div.stage: BASIL walks up and down ; and then , stopping , looks at her for a moment meditatively .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I sometimes wonder whether we should n't be happier — if we lived apart .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With a start .What d'you mean ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: We do n't seem able to get on very well . And I see no chance of things going any better .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With staring eyes .D'you mean to say you want to separate ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I think it might be better for both of us — at least for a time . Perhaps later on we might try again .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: And what 'll you do ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I should go abroad for a while .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With Mrs. Murray . Is that it ? You want to go away with her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Impatiently .No . Of course not .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I do n't believe it . You 're in love with her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You 've got no right to say that .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Have n't I ? I suppose I must shut my eyes and say nothing . You 're in love with her . D'you think I 've not seen it in these months ? That 's why you want to leave me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It 's impossible for us to live together . We shall never agree , and we shall never be happy . For God 's sake let us separate and have done with it .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You 're sick of me . You 've had all you want out of me , and now I can go . The fine lady comes along , and you send me away like a housemaid . D'you think I can n't see that you 're in love with her ? You 'd sacrifice me without a thought to save her a moment 's unpleasantness . And because you love her you hate me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It 's not true .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Can you deny that you 're in love with her ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You 're simply mad . Good heavens , I 've done nothing that could give you the least cause to be jealous .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Passionately .Will you swear that you 're not in love with her ? Swear it on your honour ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You 're mad .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With growing excitement .Swear it . You can n't . You 're simply madly in love with her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Nonsense .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Swear it . Swear it on your honour . Swear you do n't care for her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .I swear it ... on my honour .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Scornfully .It 's a lie !... And she 's just as much in love with you as you are with her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Seizing her wrists .What d'you mean ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: D'you think I have n't got eyes in my head ? I saw it that day she came here . D'you suppose she came to see me ? She despises me . I 'm not a lady . She came here to please you . She was polite to me to please you . She asked me to go and see her to please you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Trying to compose himself .It 's absurd . She was an old friend of mine . Of course she came .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I know that sort of friend . D'you think I did n't see the way she looked at you , and how she followed you with her eyes ? She simply hung on every word you said . When you smiled , she smiled . When you laughed , she laughed . Oh , I should think she was in love with you ; I know what love is , and I felt it . And when she looked at me I know she hated me because I 'd robbed her of you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Unable to contain himself .Oh , what a dog 's life it is we lead ! We 've been both utterly wretched . It can n't go on — and I only see one way out .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: That 's what you 've been brooding over this last week , is it ? Separation ! I knew there was something , and I could n't find out what it was .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I do my best to hold myself in , but sometimes I feel it 's impossible . I shall be led to saying things that we shall both regret . For Heaven 's sake let us part .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: We can n't go on having these awful quarrels . It 's too degrading . It was a horrible mistake that we ever married .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Horror-stricken .Basil !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , you must see that as well as I . We 're utterly unsuited to one another . And the baby 's death removed the only necessity that held us together .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You talk as if we only remained together because it was convenient .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Passionately .Let me go , Jenny . I can n't stand it any more . I feel as if I shall go mad .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Full of pain and anguish .It 's nothing at all to you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Jenny , I did my best for you a year ago . I gave you all I had to give . It was little enough in all conscience . Now I ask you to give me back my freedom .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Distracted .You only think of yourself . What is to become of me ?

lg.l: You 'll be much happier . It 's the best thing for both of us . I 'll do all
I can for you , and you can have your mother and sister to live here .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With a cry of grief and passion .But I love you , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You !! Why , you 've tortured me for six months beyond all endurance . You 've made all my days a burden to me . You 've made my life a perfect hell .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Gives a long groan of horror and dismay .Oh !

div.stage: They stand facing one another , when the housemaid , FANNY , comes in .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Mr. Halliwell .

div.stage: JOHN comes in . JENNY , after taking his hand , sinks down on a chair , paying no attention to the following conversation ; she stares in front of her , quite distraught . BASIL tries with all his might to appear calm and natural .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Hulloa , what are you doing in these parts ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How d'you do , Mrs. Kent ? I 've been having an early lunch at Richmond , and I thought I 'd just drop in on my way back . As it was Saturday afternoon I thought I might find you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 'm sure we 're delighted to see you .JOHN gives a side-glance at JENNY , and slightly raises his eyebrows .But you 've only just come in time , because I 've got to go up to town . We might travel up together .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Where are you going , Basil ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: To Chancery Lane , to see my agent on business .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Suspiciously .On Saturday afternoon ? Why , he wo n't be there .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I have an appointment with him .

div.stage: JENNY does not answer , but is obviously unconvinced . JOHN , somewhat embarrassed , exerts himself to make conversation .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I was thinking as I came along that one must lead quite an idyllic existence in the suburbs — with the river — and one 's little garden .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Ironically .And the spectacle of the fifty little houses opposite all exactly like one another .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And the quiet is perfectly enchanting .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , yes . The only vehicles that disturb the peaceful seclusion are the milk-cart and the barrel-organs . It 's quite idyllic .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I think it 's a very nice neighbourhood . And you get such a superior class of people here .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Looking at his watch . There 's a train at 4. 15 .I 'll just go and change .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right , hurry up .

div.stage: BASIL goes out of the room . JENNY at once springs to her feet and goes towards JOHN . She is distracted and hardly knows what she says .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Can I trust you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What d'you mean ?

div.stage: She stares into his eyes , doubting , trying to see whether he will be willing to help her .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You used to be a good sort . You never looked down on me because I was a barmaid . Tell me I can trust you , John . There 's no one I can speak to , and I feel if I do n't speak I shall go off my head .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What is the matter ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Will you tell me the truth if I ask you something ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: On your oath ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: On my oath .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: After a momentary pause .Is there anything between Basil and Mrs. Murray ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Aghast .No . Certainly not .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: How d'you know ? Are you sure ? You would n't tell me , if there was . You 're all against me because I 'm not a lady .... Oh , I 'm so unhappy .

div.stage: She tries to restrain her tears , she is half-hysterical . JOHN stares at her , surprised , at a loss for words .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: If you only knew what a life we lead ! He calls it a dog 's life , and he 's right .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I thought you got on so well .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , before you we 've always kept up appearances . He 's ashamed to let you know he regrets he ever married me . He wants to separate .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Impatiently .Oh , do n't look so surprised . You 're not an utter fool , are you ? He proposed it to-day before you came in . We 'd been having one of our rows .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But what on earth is it all about ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: God knows !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It 's nonsense . It can only be a little passing quarrel . You must expect to have those .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: No , it is n't . No , it is n't . He does n't love me . He 's in love with your sister-in-law .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It 's impossible .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: He 's always there . He was there twice last week and twice the week before .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How d'you know ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I 've followed him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You followed him in the street , Jenny ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Defiantly .Yes . If I 'm not ladylike enough for him , I need n't play the lady there . You 're shocked now , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I would n't presume to judge you , Jenny .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: And I 've read his letters , too — because I wanted to know what he was doing . I steamed one open , and he saw it , and he never said a word .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good heavens , why did you do it ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Because I can n't live unless I know the truth . I thought it was Mrs. Murray 's handwriting .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Was it from her ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: No . It was a receipt from the coal merchant . I could see how he despised me when he looked at the envelope — I did n't stick it down again very well . And I saw him smile when he found it was only a receipt .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Upon my word , I do n't think you 've got much cause to be jealous .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , you do n't know . Last Tuesday he was dining there , and you should have seen the state he was in . He was so restless he could n't sit still . He looked at his watch every minute . His eyes simply glittered with excitement , and I could almost hear his heart beating .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It can n't be true .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: He never loved me . He married me because he thought it was his duty . And then when the baby died — he thought I 'd entrapped him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He did n't say so .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: No . He never says anything — but I saw it in his eyes .Passionately clasping her hands .Oh , you do n't know what our life is . For days he does n't say a word except to answer my questions . And the silence simply drives me mad . I should n't mind if he blackguarded me . I 'd rather he hit me than simply look and look . I can see he 's keeping himself in . He 's said more to-day than he 's ever said before . I knew it was getting towards the end .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a helpless gesture .I 'm very sorry .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , do n't you pity me , too . I 've had a great deal too much pity . I do n't want it . Basil married me from pity . Oh , I wish he had n't . I can n't stand the unhappiness .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gravely .You know , Jenny , he 's a man of honour .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , I know he 's a man of honour . I wish he had a little less of it . One does n't want a lot of fine sentiments in married life . They do n't work .... Oh , why could n't I fall in love with a man of my own class ? I should have been so much happier . I used to be so proud that Basil was n't a clerk , or something in the City . He 's right , we shall never be happy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Trying to calm her .Oh , yes , you will . You must n't take things too seriously .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: It is n't a matter of yesterday , or to-day , or to-morrow . I can n't alter myself . He knew I was n't a lady when he married me . My father had to bring up five children on two-ten a week . You can n't expect a man to send his daughters to a boarding-school at Brighton on that , and have them finished in Paris .... He does n't say a word when I do something or say something a lady would n't — but he purses up his lips , and looks .... Then I get so mad that I do things just to aggravate him . Sometimes I try to be vulgar . One learns a good deal in a bar in the City , and I know so well the things to say that 'll make Basil curl up . I want to get a bit of revenge out of him sometimes , and I know exactly where he 's raw and where I can hurt him .With a laugh of scorn .You should see the way he looks when I do n't eat properly , or when I call a man a Johnny .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Drily .It opens up endless possibilities of domestic unhappiness .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , I know it is n't fair to him , but I lose my head . I can n't always be refined . Sometimes I can n't help breaking out . I feel I must let myself go .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why do n't you separate , then ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Because I love him . Oh , John , you do n't know how I love him . I 'd do anything to make him happy . I 'd give my life if he wanted it . Oh , I can n't say it , but when I think of him my heart burns so that sometimes I can hardly breathe . I can never show him that he 's all in the world to me ; I try to make him love me , and I only make him hate me . What can I do to show him ? Ah , if he only knew , I 'm sure he 'd not regret that he married me . I feel — I feel as if my heart was full of music , and yet something prevents me from ever bringing it out .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: D'you think he means it seriously when he talks of separation ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: He 's been brooding over it . I know him so well , I knew there was something he was thinking over . Oh , John , I could n't live without him . I 'd rather die . If he leaves me , I swear I 'll kill myself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Walking up and down .I wish I could help you . I do n't see anything I can do .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , yes , there is . Speak to your sister-in-law . Ask her to have mercy on me . Perhaps she does n't know what she 's doing . Tell her I love him .... Take care . There 's Basil . If he knew what I 'd said he 'd never speak to me again .

div.stage: BASIL comes in , dressed in a frock-coat ; with a tall hat in his hand .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 'm ready . We 've just got time to catch the train .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right . Good-bye , Mrs. Kent .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Keeping her eyes fixed on BASIL .Good-bye .

div.stage: The two men go out . JENNY runs to the door and calls out .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Basil , I want you a moment , Basil !

div.stage: BASIL appears at the door .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Are you really going to Chancery Lane ?

div.stage: BASIL makes a movement of impatience and goes out again without answering .

lg.l: Oh , well , I 'm going to see that for myself .
Fanny !... Bring my hat and my jacket . Quick !

div.stage: She runs to the window and looks out at BASIL and JOHN going away . FANNY appears with the clothes . JENNY hurriedly puts them on .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: As FANNY is helping her .What time is it ?

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Looking up at the clock .Five minutes past four .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I think I can catch it . He said 4. 15 .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Will you be in to tea , mum ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I do n't know .She runs to the door and rushes out .

div.stage: END OF THE SECOND ACT .

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

p.stage: A luxuriously furnished drawing-room at MRS. MURRAY 'S house in Charles Street , Mayfair . Everything in it is beautiful , but suggests in the owner good taste rather than originality .

div.stage: HILDA is seated near a tea-table , elaborately gowned , and with her is MABEL . MR. ROBERT BRACKLEY is sitting down , a stout , round-faced man , clean-shaven and very bald ; about forty ; he is attired in the height of fashion , in a frock-coat , patent-leather boots and an eye-glass . He talks very quickly , in a careless frivolous fashion , and is always much amused at what he says .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: What is the time , Mr. Brackley ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: I sha n't tell you again .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: How brutal of you !

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: There 's something unhealthy in your passion for information . I 've already told you five times .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: It 's very unflattering to us who 've been doing our little best to amuse you .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I can n't imagine what 's happened to John . He promised to fetch me here .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: He 's sure to come if you 'll only wait patiently .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: But I hate waiting patiently .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You should n't have let him out of your sight .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: He went to Putney after luncheon to see your friend Mr. Kent . Have you seen him lately ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: John ? I saw him at the Martins yesterday .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Slyly .I meant Mr. Kent .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Indifferently .Yes . He called the other day .To change the conversation .You 're unusually silent , Mr. Brackley .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Smiling .I have nothing whatever to say .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: That 's usually when clever people talk most .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Are you doing anything now ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Oh yes , I 'm writing a play in blank verse .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You brave man . What is it about ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Cleopatra .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Dear me ! Shakespeare wrote a play about Cleopatra , did n't he ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: I daresay . I have n't read it . Shakespeare bores me . He lived so long ago .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Of course there are people who read him .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Are there ? What do they look like ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Smiling .They bear no distinctive mark of their eccentricity .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: The English are so original .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I think I shall go and ring up the flat . I wonder if John has gone straight home .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Do . I 'm growing very uneasy about him .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Laughing .You absurd creature .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You talk more nonsense than anyone I ever met .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: That 's my stock in trade . You do n't imagine people would read my poems if they knew that I was sober , industrious , and economical . As a matter of fact I lead the virtuous life of a clergyman 's daughter , but not a reviewer would notice me if he knew it .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: And the little things that the indiscreet read of in the papers ....

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Are merely another proof of my passion for duty . The British public wants its poets to lead romantic lives .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Are you ever serious ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: May I come to lunch with you on Thursday ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: A little surprised .Certainly . But why on Thursday ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Because on that day I intend to ask you to marry me .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: With a smile .I 'm sorry , I 've just remembered that I 'm lunching out .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: You break my heart .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: On the contrary , I provide you with the materials for a sonnet .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Wo n't you marry me ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Amused .I 'm not in the least in love with you .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: People who propose to marry should ask themselves if they can look forward with equanimity to breakfasting opposite one another for an indefinite number of years .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You 're very unromantic .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: My dear lady , if you want romance I 'll send you my complete works bound in vellum . I 've ground out ten volumes of romance to Phyllis and Chloe and heaven knows who . The Lord save me from a romantic wife .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: But I 'm afraid I 'm hopelessly romantic .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Well , six months of marriage with a poet will cure you .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I 'd rather not be cured .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Wo n't you be in to luncheon on Thursday ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: No .

div.stage: The BUTLER comes in .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Mr. Halliwell , Mr. Kent .

div.stage: BASIL and JOHN appear , and at the same moment MABEL comes in from the room in which she has been telephoning .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: To JOHN .Wretched creature ! I 've been trying to ring you up .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Have I kept you waiting ? I went down to Chancery Lane with Basil .

div.stage: JOHN turns to shake hands with HILDA and BRACKLEY , while BASIL , who has said how d'you do to HILDA , comes down to speak to MABEL . The conversation between MABEL and BASIL is in an undertone .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: How d'you do . You must scold me for keeping John so long .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I did n't really want him , you know .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Pointing with his head to BRACKLEY .I say , who is that ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Robert Brackley . Do n't you know him ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: The poet ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Of course . They say he 'd have been given the Laureateship if it had n't been abolished at Tennyson 's death .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Tightening his lips .He 's rather a low blackguard , is n't he ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Heavens , what 's the matter with him , poor man ? He 's Hilda 's latest celebrity . He pretends to adore her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Do n't you remember the Grange case that he was mixed up in ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: In tones of surprise .But , my dear Mr. Kent , that was two years ago .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Mr. Kent , I want to introduce you to Mr. Brackley .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Going up .How d'you do .

div.stage: JOHN comes down to his wife .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Wretched creature !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I say , Mabel , is Basil often here ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I do n't know . I met him here last week .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why the Dickens does he come ? He 's got no business to .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: You brought him yourself to-day .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I did n't . He insisted on coming — when I said I had to fetch you .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Perhaps he came to see me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Fiddledidee ! I think you ought to speak to Hilda about it .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: My dear John , are you mad ? She 'd jump down my throat .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why does she let him hang about her ? She must know she 's turning his silly head .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: I daresay she wants to prove to him that he showed very bad taste a year ago . It is rather annoying when you 're attached to a young man that he should go and marry somebody else .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , I do n't think she 's playing the game , and I shall tell her so .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: She 'll snub you awfully .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't care .... Look here , you make a diversion so that I can get hold of her .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Dryly .I do n't know . Exercise your invention .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Going towards the others .Hilda , John is clamouring for some tea .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Coming down .Why on earth can n't he help himself ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My native modesty prevents .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: That 's quite a new trait in you .

div.stage: HILDA sits down and pours out tea for JOHN . He looks at her silently .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You 've been lunching at Richmond ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes .... Then I went on to Putney .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You 've been making quite a day of it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Taking the cup .I say , old gal — you 're not going to make a fool of yourself , are you ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Opening her eyes .Oh , I hope not . Why ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I thought it might have slipped your memory that Basil was married about a year ago .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Freezing .What on earth d'you mean ?CallingMabel .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: One moment .... You can give me a little conversation , can n't you ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 're going to bore me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good-humouredly .I assure you I 'm not .... Is n't Basil here rather often ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I wonder you have n't learnt to mind your own business , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't you think it 's rather rough on that poor little woman in Putney ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: With a suspicion of contempt .I went down to see her . I thought she was vulgar and pretentious . I 'm afraid I can n't arouse any interest in her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gently .She may be vulgar , but she told me her love was like music in her heart . Do n't you think she must have suffered awfully to get hold of a thought like that ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: After a pause , changing suddenly both voice and manner .And d'you think I 've not suffered , John ? I 'm so unhappy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do you really care for him ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: In a low voice hoarse with passion .No , I do n't care for him . I worship the very ground he treads on .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Very gravely .Then you must do as you think best .... You 're playing the most dangerous game in the world . You 're playing with human hearts .... Good-bye .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Taking his hand .Good-bye , John . You 're not angry with me because I was horrid .... I 'm glad you told me about his wife . Now I shall know what to do .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mabel .

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Coming forward .Yes , we really must be going . I 've not seen my precious baby for two hours .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Taking both her hands .Good-bye , you happy child . You 've got a precious baby , and you 've got a husband you love . What can you want more ?

sp.speaker: MABEL
sp.p: Flippantly .I want a motor-car .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Kissing her .Good-bye , darling .

div.stage: MABEL and JOHN go out .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: I like this room , Mrs. Murray . It never seems to say to you : now it 's really time for you to go away , as some drawing-rooms do .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Recovering her serenity .I suppose it 's the furniture . I 'm thinking of changing it .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: With a smile .Upon my word , that almost suggests that I 've outstayed my welcome .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Gaily .I should n't have said that if I did n't know that nothing would induce you to go till you wanted to .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Rising .You know me like your glove . But it really is growing monstrous late .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You must n't go till you 've told me who the fair charmer was I saw you with at the play last night .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Ah , the green-eyed monster !

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Laughing .Do n't be so absurd , but I thought you 'd like to know her yellow hair was dyed .

div.stage: BASIL looks over the pages of a book , somewhat annoyed that HILDA takes no notice of him .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Of course it was dyed . That was just the charm of it . Any woman can have yellow hair naturally : there 's no more credit in that than in having it blue or green .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I 've always wanted to make mine purple .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Do n't you think women ought to be artificial ? It 's just as much their duty to rouge their cheeks and powder their noses as it is for them to wear nice frocks .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: But I know many women who wear horrid frocks .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Oh , those are the others . I treat them as non-existent .

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: There are only two sorts of women in the world — the women who powder their noses and the others .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: And who are they if you please ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: I have n't examined the matter very carefully , but I understand they are clergymen 's daughters by profession .

div.stage: He shakes hands with her .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: It 's so nice of you to have come .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: Nodding at BASIL .Good-bye .... May I come again soon ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Looking at him quickly .Were you serious just now , or were you laughing at me ?

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: I 've never been more serious in my life .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Then perhaps I shall be in to luncheon on Thursday after all .

sp.speaker: BRACKLEY
sp.p: A thousand thanks . Good-bye .

div.stage: He nods to BASIL and goes out . HILDA looks at BASIL with a smile .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Is that a very interesting book ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Putting it down .I thought that man was never going away .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Laughing .I suspect he thought precisely the same of you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Ill-temperedly .What an ass he is ! How can you stand him ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I 'm rather attached to him . I do n't take everything he says very seriously . And young men ought to be foolish .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: He did n't strike me as so juvenile as all that .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: He 's only forty , poor thing — and I 've never known a coming young man who was less than that .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: He 's a young man with a very bald head .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Amused .I wonder why you dislike him !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a jealous glance , icily .I thought he was n't admitted into decent houses .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Opening her eyes .He comes here , Mr. Kent .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Unable to restrain his ill-temper .Do n't you know that he 's been mixed up in every scandal for the last twenty years ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Good-humouredly , seeing that BASIL is merely jealous .There must be people in the world to provide gossip for their neighbours .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It 's no business of mine . I have no right to talk to you like this .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I wonder why you do it ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Almost savagely .Because I love you .

div.stage: There is a little pause .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: With a smile , ironically .Wo n't you have some more tea , Mr. Kent ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Going up to her , speaking with a sort of vehement gravity .You do n't know what I 've suffered . You do n't know what a hell my life is .... I tried so hard to prevent myself from coming here . When I married I swore I 'd break with all my old friends .... When I married I found I loved you .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I can n't listen to you if you talk like that .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: D'you want me to go ?

div.stage: She does not answer for a moment , but walks up and down in agitation . At last she stops and faces him .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Did you hear me tell Mr. Brackley to come on Thursday ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: He 's asked me to be his wife . And on Thursday I shall give him an answer .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Hilda !

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Earnestly .It 's you who 've driven me into it .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Hilda , what are you going to say to him ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I do n't know — perhaps , yes ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , Hilda , Hilda , you do n't care for him ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Shrugging her shoulders .He amuses me . I dare say we should get on very well together .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Passionately .Oh , you can n't . You do n't know what you 're doing . I thought — I thought you loved me .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: It 's because I love you that I shall marry Mr. Brackley .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , it 's absurd . I wo n't let you . You 're making us both utterly wretched . I wo n't let you sacrifice our happiness . Oh , Hilda , I love you . I can n't live without you . At first I tried to resist seeing you . I used to pass your door and look up at your windows ; and the door seemed as if it were waiting for me . And at the end of the street I used to look back . Oh , how I used to want to come in and see you once more ! I thought if I saw you just once , I should get over it . And at last I could n't help myself . I 'm so weak . Do you despise me ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Almost in a whisper .I do n't know .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: And you were so kind I could n't help coming again . I thought I did no harm .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I saw you were unhappy .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I should think I was unhappy . For months I 've dreaded going home . When I saw my house as I walked along I almost turned sick . You do n't know how fervently I 've wished that I 'd got killed in the war . I can n't go on .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: But you must . It 's your duty .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I think I 've had enough of duty and honour . I 've used up all my principles in the last year .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Do n't say that , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: After all , it 's my own fault . I brought it on myself , and I must take the consequences .... But I have n't the strength , I do n't love her .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Then do n't let her ever find it out . Be kind to her , and gentle and forbearing .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I can n't be kind and gentle and forbearing day after day , for weeks , and months , and years .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I thought you were a brave man . They would n't have given you that medal if you 'd been a coward .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , my dearest , it 's not hard to risk your life in the midst of battle . I can do that — but this needs more strength than I 've got . I tell you I can n't endure it .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Tenderly .But it 'll get better . You 'll get used to one another , and you 'll understand one another better .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: We 're too different . It 's impossible for it to get better . We can n't even go on as we have been . I 've felt that the end was coming .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: But try — try for my sake .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You do n't know what it is . Everything she says , everything she does , jars upon me so frightfully . I try to restrain myself . I clench my teeth to prevent myself from breaking out at her . Sometimes I can n't help it , and I say things that I 'd give anything to have left unsaid . She 's dragging me down . I 'm getting as common and vulgar as she is .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: How can you say that of your wife ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Do n't you think I must have gone through a good deal before I could acknowledge to myself what she was ? I 'm chained to her for all my life . And when I look into the future — I see her a vulgar , slatternly shrew like her mother , and myself abject , degraded , and despicable . The woman never tires in her conflict with the man , and in the end he always succumbs . A man , when he marries a woman like that , thinks he 's going to lift her up to his own station . The fool ! It 's she who drags him down to hers .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Much disturbed , rising from her seat .I wanted you to be so happy .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Going towards her .Hilda !

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: No — do n't .... Please !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: If it were n't for you I could n't have lived . It was only by seeing you that I gathered courage to go on with it . And each time I came here I loved you more passionately .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Oh , why did you come ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I could n't help it . I knew it was poison , but I loved the poison . I would give my whole soul for one look of your eyes .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: If you care for me at all , do your duty like a brave man — and let me respect you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Say that you love me , Hilda .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Distracted .You 're making our friendship impossible . Do n't you see that you 're preventing me from ever having you here again ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I can n't help it .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I ought never to have seen you again . I thought there was no harm in your coming , and I — I could n't bear to lose you altogether .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Even if I never see you again , I must tell you now that I love you . I made you suffer , I was blind . But I love you with all my heart , Hilda . All day I think of you , and I dream of you in the night . I long to take you in my arms and kiss you , to kiss your lips , and your beautiful hair , and your hands . My whole soul is yours , Hilda .

div.stage: He goes towards her again to take her in his arms .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Oh , no , go away . For God 's sake , go now . I can n't bear it .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Hilda , I can n't live without you .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Have mercy on me . Do n't you see how weak I am ? Oh , God help me !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You do n't love me ?

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Vehemently .You know I love you . But because of my great love I beseech you to do your duty .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: My duty is to be happy . Let us go where we can love one another — away from England , to a land where love is n't sinful and ugly .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Oh , Basil , let us try to walk straight . Think of your wife , who loves you also — as much as I do . You 're all the world to her . You can n't treat her so shamefully .

div.stage: She puts her handkerchief to her eyes , and BASIL gently takes away her hand .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Do n't cry , Hilda . I can n't bear it .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: In broken tones .Do n't you understand that we could never respect ourselves again if we did that poor creature such a fearful wrong ? She would be always between us with her tears and her sorrows . I tell you I could n't bear it . Have mercy on me — if you love me at all .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Wavering .Hilda , it 's too hard . I can n't leave you .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: You must . I know it 's better to do our duty . For my sake , dearest , go back to your wife , and do n't let her ever know that you love me . It 's because we 're stronger than she that we must sacrifice ourselves .

div.stage: He leans his head on his hands , and sighs deeply . For a while they remain in silence . At last , with another sigh , he gets up .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I do n't know any longer what 's right and what 's wrong . It all seems confused . It 's very hard .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Hoarsely .It 's just as hard for me , Basil .

lg.l: Good-bye , then . I dare say you 're right . And perhaps
I should only make you very unhappy .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Good-bye , my dearest .

div.stage: He bends down and kisses her hands . She stifles a sob . He goes slowly to the door , with his back turned to her ; and then HILDA , unable to endure it , gives a groan .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Basil . Do n't go .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a cry of joy .Ah ! Hilda .

div.stage: He clasps her passionately in his arms .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Oh , I can n't bear it . I wo n't lose you . Basil , say you love me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: In a madness of joy .Yes . I love you with all my heart .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I could have borne it if you 'd been happy .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Now nothing can separate us , Hilda . You belong to me for ever .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: God help me ! What have I done ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: If we lose our souls , what does it matter ? We gain the whole world .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Oh , Basil , I want your love . I want your love so badly .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Will you come with me , Hilda ? I can take you to a land where the whole earth speaks only of love — and where only love and youth and beauty matter .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Let us go where we can be together always . We have so short a time ; let us snatch all the happiness we can .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Kissing her again .My darling .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Oh , Basil , Basil ....She starts away .Take care !

div.stage: The BUTLER comes in .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Mrs. Kent .

div.stage: JENNY enters hurriedly , as he gives her name . The BUTLER at once goes out .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Jenny !

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I 've caught you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Trying to be urbane — to HILDAI think you know my wife .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: In a loud angry voice .Oh , yes , I know her . You need n't introduce me . I 've come for my husband .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Jenny , what are you saying ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't want any of your Society shams . I 've come here to speak out .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: To HILDA .Would you mind leaving us alone ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Also to HILDA , passionately .No , I want to speak to you . You 're trying to get my husband from me . He 's my husband .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Be quiet , Jenny . Are you mad ? Mrs. Murray , for God 's sake leave us . She 'll insult you .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You think of her , you do n't think of me . You do n't care how much I suffer .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Taking her arm .Come away , Jenny .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Shaking him off .I wo n't . You 're afraid to let me see her .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Pale and trembling , conscience-stricken .Let her speak .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Going up to HILDA threateningly .She is at a loss for words violent enough .You 're stealing my husband from me . Oh , you ....

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: I do n't want to make you unhappy , Mrs. Kent .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You can n't get round me with polite words . I 'm sick of all that . I want to speak straight .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: To HILDA .Please go . You can do no good .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Still more vehemently .You 're stealing my husband from me . You 're a wicked woman .

sp.speaker: HILDA
sp.p: Almost in a whisper .If you like I 'll promise you never to see your husband again .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With angry scorn .Much good your promises will do me . I would n't believe a word you said . I know what Society ladies are . We know all about them in the City .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: To HILDA .You must leave us alone .

div.stage: He opens the door , and she goes out , looking away from him .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Savagely .She 's frightened of me . She dare n't stand up to me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: As HILDA goes .I 'm so sorry .

sp.speaker: JENNY
