sp.p: You 're sorry for her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Turning on her .Yes , I am . What d'you mean by coming here and behaving like this ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I 've caught you at last .... You liar ! You dirty liar ! You told me you were going to Chancery Lane .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I have been to Chancery Lane .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , I know you have — for five minutes . It was only an excuse . You might just as well have come here straight .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Angrily .How dare you follow me ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I 've got a right to follow you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Unable to contain himself .What d'you want here ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I want you . D'you think I did n't guess what was going on ? I saw you come in with Halliwell . Then I saw him go out with his wife . Then another man went out , and I knew you were alone with her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Sharply .How did you know ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I gave the butler a sovereign , and he told me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Looking for a word to express his contempt .Oh , you ... you cad ! It 's only what I should have expected you to do .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: And then I waited for you , and you did n't come . And at last I could n't wait any longer .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Well , you 've finished it now .

div.stage: JENNY catches sight of a photograph of BASIL , standing on a table .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Pointing to it .What 's she got your photograph here for ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I gave it to Mrs. Murray before I was married .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: She 's got no right to keep it there .

div.stage: She takes the photograph and flings it violently on the floor .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Jenny , what are you doing ?

div.stage: JENNY digs her heel into it savagely , viciously .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Hissing the words .Oh , I hate her . I hate her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Striving to contain himself .You drive me perfectly mad . You 'll make me say things that I shall regret all my life . For Heaven 's sake , go .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I sha n't go till you come with me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Beside himself .I choose to remain .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: What d'you mean ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Look here , until to-day I swear to you before God that I 've never done anything or said anything that you could n't have known . Do you believe me ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: I do n't believe that you 're not in love with that woman .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I do n't ask you to .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: What !

lg.l: I said , until to-day I 've been absolutely faithful to you . Heaven knows ,
I 've tried to do my duty . I 've done all I could to make you happy . And
I 've struggled with all my might to love you .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Say it out if you 've got anything to say , I 'm not afraid to hear .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I do n't wish to deceive you . It 's best that you should know what has happened .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Scornfully .Now for another thumping lie .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: This afternoon I told Hilda I loved her .... And she loves me too .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With a cry of rage .Oh !

div.stage: She hits at his face with her umbrella , but he wards the blow , and , snatching the umbrella from her , throws it away .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You 've brought it on yourself . You made me too unhappy .

div.stage: JENNY , panting and bewildered , stands helpless , trying to control herself .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: And now it 's the end . The life we led was impossible . I tried to do something that was beyond my power . I 'm going away . I can n't and I wo n't live with you any longer .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Frightened at herself and at what he says .Basil , you do n't mean that ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 've struggled against it for months . And now I 'm beaten .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: You 've got me to count with . I wo n't let you go .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Bitterly .What more d'you want ? Is n't it enough that you 've ruined my whole life ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Hoarsely .You do n't love me ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I never loved you .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Why did you marry me ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Because you made me .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: In a whisper .You never loved me — even at the beginning ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Basil !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It 's too late now to keep it in . I must tell you and have done with it . You 've been having it out for months — now it 's my turn .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Going up to him and trying to put her arm round his neck .But I love you , Basil . I 'll make you love me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shrinking from her .Do n't touch me !

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: With a movement of despair .I really think you loathe me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: For Heaven 's sake , Jenny , let us finish with it . I 'm very sorry . I do n't wish to be unkind to you . But you must have seen that — that I did n't care for you . What 's the good of going on humbugging , and pretending , and making ourselves utterly wretched ?

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Yes , I 've seen it . But I would n't believe it . When I 've put my hand on your shoulder , I 've seen that you could hardly help shuddering . And sometimes when I 've kissed you , I 've seen you put out all your strength to prevent yourself from pushing me away .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Jenny , I can n't help it if I do n't love you . I can n't help it if I — if I love some one else .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Dazed and cowed .What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 'm going away .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: God knows .

div.stage: There is a knock at the door .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Come in .

div.stage: The BUTLER enters with a note , which he gives to BASIL .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Mrs. Murray told me to give you this note , Sir .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Taking it .Thank you .

div.stage: He opens and reads it as the SERVANT goes out of the room , then looks up at JENNY , who is anxiously watching him .
Reading . ] “ You may tell your wife that I 've made up my mind to marry Mr. Brackley . I will never see you again . ”

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: What does she mean ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Bitterly .Is n't it clear ? Some one has asked her to marry him , and she means to accept .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: But you said she loved you .

div.stage: He shrugs his shoulders without answering . JENNY goes up to him imploringly .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , Basil , if it 's true , give me another chance . She does n't love you as I love you . I 've been selfish and quarrelsome and exacting , but I 've always loved you . Oh , do n't leave me , Basil . Let me try once more if I can n't make you care for me .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Looking down , hoarsely .I 'm very sorry . It 's too late .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Despairingly .Oh , God , what shall I do ? And even though she 's going to marry somebody else , you care for her better than any one else in the world ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: In a whisper .Yes .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: And even if she does marry that other man she 'll love you still . There 's no room for me between you . I can go away like a discharged servant .... Oh , God ! oh , God ! what have I done to deserve it ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Touched by her utter misery .I 'm very sorry to make you so unhappy .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: Oh , do n't pity me . D'you think I want your pity now ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: You had better come away , Jenny .

sp.speaker: JENNY
sp.p: No . You 've told me you do n't want me any more . I shall go my own way .

lg.stage: Looks at her for a moment , hesitating ; then shrugs his shoulders .
lg.l: Then good-bye .

div.stage: He goes out , and JENNY , looking after him , passes her hand wearily over her forehead .

lg.l: He 's so glad to go ....
They 've got no room for me .

div.stage: She takes up from the floor the photograph on which she stamped , and looks at it ; then sinks down , burying her face in her hands , and bursts into a passion of tears .
END OF THE THIRD ACT .

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT .

p.stage: The scene is the same as in the Second Act , the drawing-room at Basil 's house in Putney . BASIL is sitting at the table , with his head in his hands . He looks tired and worn ; his face is very white , and there are great black lines under his eyes . His hair is dishevelled . On the table lies a revolver .

div.stage: A knock at the door .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Without looking up .Come in .

div.stage: FANNY enters .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Subdued and pale .I came to see if you wanted anything , sir .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Looking up at her slowly , his voice is dull and hoarse .No .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Shall I open the windows , Sir ? It 's a beautiful morning .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: No , I 'm cold . Make up the fire .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Would n't you like a cup of tea ? You ought to ‘ ave something after not going to bed all night .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I do n't want anything .... Do n't worry , there 's a good woman .

div.stage: FANNY puts coals on the fire , while BASIL listlessly watches her .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: How long is it since you sent the telegrams ?

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: I took them the moment the office was opened .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: What 's the time ?

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Well , sir , it must be ‘ alf-past nine by now .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Good Heavens , how slowly the hours go . I thought the night would never end .... Oh , God , what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: I 'll make you a strong cup of tea . If you do n't ‘ ave something to pull you together — I do n't know what 'll ‘ appen to you .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Yes , make it quickly , I 'm thirsty .... And I 'm so cold .

div.stage: A ring at the front door is heard .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Jumping up .There 's some one at the door , Fanny . Hurry up .

div.stage: She goes out , and he follows her to the door of the room .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Fanny , do n't let any one up beside Mr. Halliwell . Say I can see no one .He waits for a moment , anxiously .Is that you , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Outside .Yes .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: To himself .Thank God !

div.stage: JOHN comes in .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I thought you were never coming . I begged you to come at once .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I started immediately I got your wire .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It seems hours since the girl went to the post-office .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Hoarsely .Do n't you know ? I thought I had said it in my telegram .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You simply wired that you were in great trouble .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I suppose I thought you 'd see it in the papers .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What on earth d'you mean ? I 've not seen a paper . Where 's your wife ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: After a pause , almost in a whisper .She 's dead .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Thunderstruck .Good God !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Impatiently .Do n't look at me like that . Is n't it plain enough ? Do n't you understand ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But she was all right yesterday .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Dully .Yes . She was all right yesterday .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: For goodness sake tell me what you mean , Basil .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: She 's dead .... And she was all right yesterday .

div.stage: JOHN does not understand . He is greatly distressed , and does not know what to say .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I killed her — as surely as if I 'd strangled her with my own hands .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What d'you mean ? She 's not really dead !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: In agony .She threw herself into the river last night .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How awful !

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Have n't you got something more to say than how awful ? I feel as if I were going mad .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But I can n't understand ! Why did she do it ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh — yesterday we had an awful row ... before you came .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Then she followed me to ... to your sister-in-law 's . And she came up and made another scene . Then I lost my head . I was so furious , I do n't know what I said . I was mad . I told her I 'd have nothing more to do with her .... Oh , I can n't bear it , I can n't bear it .

div.stage: He breaks down and hides his face in his hands , sobbing .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Come , Basil — pull yourself together a bit .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Looking up despairingly .I can hear her voice now . I can see the look of her eyes . She asked me to give her another chance , and I refused . It was so pitiful to hear the way she appealed to me , only I was mad , and I could n't feel it .

div.stage: FANNY comes in with the cup of tea , which BASIL silently takes and drinks .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: To JOHN .He ai n't slept a wink all night , sir .... No more ‘ ave I , for the matter of that .

div.stage: JOHN nods , but does not answer ; and FANNY , wiping her eyes with her apron , leaves the room .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I 'd give everything not to have said what I did . I 'd always held myself in before , but yesterday — I could n't .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I did n't get back here till nearly ten , and the maid told me Jenny had just gone out . I thought she 'd gone back to her mother 's .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: And soon after a constable came up and asked me to go down to the river . He said there 'd been an accident .... She was dead . A man had seen her walk along the tow-path and throw herself in .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Where is she now ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Pointing to one of the doors .In there .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Will you take me in ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Go in alone , John . I dare n't , I 'm afraid to look at her . I can n't bear the look on her face .... I killed her — as surely as if I 'd strangled her with my own hands . I 've been looking at the door all night , and once I thought I heard a sound . I thought she was coming to reproach me for killing her .

div.stage: JOHN goes to the door , and as he opens it , BASIL averts his head . When JOHN shuts the door after him , he looks at it with staring , frightened eyes , half mad with agony . He tries to contain himself . After a while JOHN comes back , very quietly .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Whispering .What does she look like ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: There 's nothing to be afraid of , Basil . She might be sleeping .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Clenching his hands .But the ghastly pallor ....

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gravely .She 's happier than she would ever have been if she 'd lived .

div.stage: BASIL sighs deeply .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Seeing the revolver .What 's this for ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With a groan of self-contempt .I tried to kill myself in the night .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: H 'm !

div.stage: He takes the cartridges out and puts the revolver in his pocket .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Bitterly .Oh , do n't be afraid , I have n't got the pluck .... I was afraid to go on living . I thought if I killed myself it would be a reparation for her death . I went down to the river , and I walked along the tow-path to the same spot — but I could n't do it . The water looked so black and cold and pitiless . And yet she did it so easily . She just walked along and threw herself in .A pause .Then I came back , and I thought I 'd shoot myself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: D'you think that would have done any one much good ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I despised myself . I felt I had n't the right to live , and I thought it would be easier just to pull a trigger .... People say it 's cowardly to destroy oneself , they do n't know what courage it wants . I could n't face the pain — and then , I do n't know what 's on the other side . After all , it may be true that there 's a cruel , avenging God , who will punish us to all eternity if we break His unknown laws .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'm very glad you sent for me . You had better come back to London , and stay with me for the present .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: And d'you know what happened in the night ? I could n't go to bed . I felt I could never sleep again — and then , presently , I dozed off quite quietly in my chair . And I slept as comfortably — as if Jenny were n't lying in there , cold and dead . And the maid pities me because she thinks I passed as sleepless a night as she did .

div.stage: A sound of voices is heard outside , in altercation . FANNY comes in .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Please , sir , Mr. James .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Angrily .I wo n't see him .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: He wo n't go away , I told ‘ im you was too ill to see anybody .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I wo n't see him . I knew he 'd be round , curse him !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: After all , I suppose he has a certain right to come here — under the circumstances . Had n't you better see what he wants ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , he 'll make a scene . I shall knock him down . I 've suffered too much through him already .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Let me see him . You do n't want him to make a fuss at the inquest .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 've been thinking of that . I know the stories he and his people will make up . And the papers will get hold of it , and every one will blackguard me . They 'll say it was my fault .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: D'you mind if I have a talk to him ? I think I can save you from all that .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders , impatiently .Do whatever you like .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: To FANNY .Show him up , Fanny .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Then I shall go .

div.stage: JOHN nods , and BASIL goes out by the door next to that of the room in which JENNY is lying . JAMES BUSH appears .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Grave and cold .Good morning , Mr. Bush .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Aggressively .Where 's that man ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Raising his eyebrows .It 's usual to take one 's hat off in other people 's houses .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'm a man of principle , I am ; and I keep my ‘ at on to show it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ah , well , we wo n't discuss the point .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I want to see that man .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: May I ask to whom you 're referring ? There are so many men in the world . In fact , it 's very over-crowded .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Who are you , I should like to know ?

lg.l: My name is Halliwell . I had the pleasure of meeting you at
Basil 's rooms in Bloomsbury .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Aggressively .I know that .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I beg your pardon . I thought you were asking for information .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I tell you I want to see my brother-in-law .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'm afraid you can n't .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I tell you I will see ‘ im . He 's murdered my sister . He 's a blackguard and a murderer , and I 'll tell him so to his face .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sarcastic .Take care he does n't hear you .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I want him to hear me . I 'm not frightened of him . I should just like to see him touch me now .He sidles viciously to JOHN .H 'm , you tried to keep me out , did yer ? Said I could n't come to my sister 's ‘ ouse — and kept me waitin ’ in the ‘ all like a tradesman . Oh , I 'll make you all pay for this . I 'll get my own back now . Measley set of West End curs , that 's all you are .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mr. Bush , you 'll be so good as to keep a civil tongue in your mouth while you 're here — and you 'll talk less loudly .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Scornfully .Who says so ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Looking at him quietly .I do .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Less decisively .Do n't you try and bully me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Pointing to a chair .Wo n't you sit down ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , I wo n't sit down . This ai n't the ‘ ouse that a gentleman would sit down in . I 'll be even with ‘ im yet . I 'll tell the jury a pretty story . He deserves to be strung up , he does .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I can n't tell you how extremely sorry I am for what has happened .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh , do n't try and get round me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Really , Mr. Bush , you have no reason to be indignant with me .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , I do n't think much of you , any ‘ ow .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'm very sorry . Last time we met I thought you a very amiable person . Do n't you remember , we went and had a drink together ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't say you 're not a gentleman .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Taking out his cigar-case .Wo n't you have a cigar ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Suspiciously .Look here , you 're not trying to bluff me , are you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Certainly not . I would n't dream of such a thing .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Taking a cigar .Larranaga .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With an acid smile .Nine pounds a hundred .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: That 's one and nine apiece , ai n't it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How quickly you reckon !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You must be pretty oofy to be able to afford that .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Drily .It does inspire respect , does n't it ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't know what you mean by that . But I flatter myself I know a good cigar when I see it .

div.stage: JOHN sits down , and JAMES BUSH , without thinking , follows his example .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What d'you think you 'll get out of making a row at the inquest ? Of course , there 'll be an inquest .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , I know there will . And I 'm lookin ’ forward to it , I can tell you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I would n't have said that if I 'd been you .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Quite unconscious of the construction that may be put on his last words — full of his own grievances .I 've ‘ ad something to put up with , I ‘ ave .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh , he 's treated me shockin ’ ! He simply treated me like dirt . I would n't ‘ ave stood it a minute , except for Jenny 's sake . I was n't good enough for ‘ im , if you please . And the way he used to look right through me as if I was n't there at all — Oh , I 'll be even with ‘ im now .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Never you mind . I 'm going to make it hot for ‘ im .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: D'you think that 'll do you any good ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Springing up .Yes . And I mean to ....

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Interrupting .Now sit down , there 's a good chap , and let 's have a little talk about it .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Angrily .You 're trying to bamboozle me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nonsense .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh , yes , you are . Do n't try to deny it . I can see through you as if you was a pane of glass . You people in the West End — you think you know everything .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I assure you ....

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Interrupting .But I 've had a City training , and you can lay anything you like there ai n't no flies on me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: We 're both men of the world , Mr. Bush . Will you do me a great favour as a — friend ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Suspiciously .That depends on what it is .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It 's merely to listen to me quietly for two or three minutes .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't mind doing that .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , the fact is — Basil 's going away , and he wants to get rid of the furniture and the house . What d'you think it 's worth , as an auctioneer ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Looking round .It 's a very different business what a thing 's worth , and what it 'll fetch .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Of course , but a clever man like you ....

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Now then , no bluff . I tell you it wo n't work with me .... D'you include plate and linen ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Everything .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , if it was well sold — by a man as knew his business ....

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If you sold it , for instance ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: It might fetch a hundred pounds — it might fetch a hundred and fifty .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That would n't be a bad present to make to any one , would it ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No . I think I can agree with you there .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , Basil thought of giving the entire contents of the house to your mother and sister .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: To tell you the truth , it 's no more than he ought to do .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The condition is , of course , that nothing is said at the inquest .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: With a sneer .You make me laugh . D'you think you can gag me by giving a houseful of furniture to my mother ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I had no such exalted opinion of your disinterestedness , Mr. Bush . I come to you now .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Sharply .What d'you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It appears that you owe Basil a good deal of money . Can you pay it ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Also it appears that there was some difficulty with your accounts in your last place .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: That 's a lie .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Possibly . But altogether I fancy we could make it uncommonly nasty for you if you made a fuss . If dirty linen is going to be washed in public — there 's generally a good deal to be done on both sides .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't care . I mean to get my own back . If I can only get my knife into that man — I 'll take the consequences .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: On the other hand — if you wo n't make a fuss at the inquest , I 'll give you fifty pounds .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Jumping up indignantly .Are you trying to bribe me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Calmly .Yes .

lg.l: I would ‘ ave you know that I 'm a gentleman , and what 's more , I 'm an
Englishman . And I 'm proud of it . You ought to be ashamed of yourself .
I 've never ‘ ad any one try and bribe me before .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Indifferently .Otherwise you would , doubtless , have accepted .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 've got more than half a mind to knock you down .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a slight smile .Come , come , Mr. Bush , do n't be ridiculous . You 'd far better keep quiet , you know .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Scornfully .What do you think fifty pounds is to me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a sharp look .Who spoke of fifty pounds ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You did .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You must have mistaken me . A hundred and fifty .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh !At first he is surprised , then , as the amount sinks into his mind , grows doubtful .That 's a very different pair of shoes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't ask you to say anything untrue . After all , it 's not worth while for a man of the world like you — a business man — to give way to petty spite . And we do n't want to have any scandal . That would be just as unpleasant for you as for us .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Undecided .There 's no denying that she was hysterical . If he 'd only treated me like a gentleman , I should n't have had anything to say .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: With a foxy , keen glance at JOHN .Make it two ‘ undred , and I 'll say done .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Firmly .No . You can take a hundred and fifty , or go to the devil .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh , well , ‘ and it over .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Taking a cheque out of his pocket .I 'll give you fifty now and the rest after the inquest .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: With a certain admiration .You 're a sharp ‘ un , you are .

div.stage: JOHN writes out the cheque and gives it to JAMES BUSH .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Shall I give you a receipt ? I 'm a business man , you know .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , I know ; but it 's not necessary . You 'll tell your mother and sister ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Do n't you fear . I 'm a gentleman , and I do n't go back on my friends .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now I think I 'll say good morning to you . You can understand that Basil is n't fit to see any one .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I understand . So long .

div.stage: He stretches out his hand , which JOHN shakes gravely .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good morning .

div.stage: FANNY comes in by one door as JAMES BUSH goes out by another .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: Good riddance to bad rubbish .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ah , Fanny , if there were no rogues in the world , life would really be too difficult for honest men .

div.stage: FANNY goes out , and JOHN walks to the door and calls .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Basil — he 's gone .... Where are you ?

div.stage: BASIL comes out of the room in which is lying Jenny 's body .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I did n't know you were in there .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I wonder if she forgives me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I would n't worry myself too much if I were you , Basil , old man .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: If you only knew how I despise myself !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Come , come , Basil , you must make an effort ....

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I 've not told you the worst . I feel such a cad . There 's one thought that 's been with me all night . And I can n't drive it away . It 's worse than anything else . It 's too shameful .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , it 's so despicable . And yet it 's too strong for me .... I can n't help thinking that I 'm — free .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Free ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: It 's treachery to her memory . But you do n't know what it is when your prison door is opened .As he speaks he grows more and more excited .I do n't want to die . I want to live , and I want to take life by both hands and enjoy it . I 've got such a desire for happiness . Let 's open the windows , and let the sunlight in .He goes to the window and flings it open .It 's so good just to be alive . How can I help thinking that now I can start fresh ? The slate is wiped clean , and I can begin again . I will be happy . God forgive me , I can n't help the thought . I 'm free . I made a ghastly mistake , and I suffered for it . Heaven knows how I suffered , and how hard I tried to make the best of it . It was n't all my fault . In this world we 're made to act and think things because other people have thought them good . We never have a chance of going our own way . We 're bound down by the prejudices and the morals of everybody else . For God 's sake , let us be free . Let us do this and that because we want to and because we must , not because other people think we ought .He stops suddenly in front of JOHN .Why do n't you say something ? You stare at me as if you thought me raving mad !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't know what to say .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Oh , I suppose you 're shocked and scandalised . I ought to go on posing . I ought to act the part decently to the end . You would never have had the courage to do what I did , and yet , because I 've failed , you think you can look down on me from the height of your moral elevation .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gravely .I was thinking how far a man may fall when he attempts to climb the stars .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I gave the world fine gold , and their currency is only cowrie-shells . I held up an ideal , and they sneered at me . In this world you must wallow in the trough with the rest of them .... The only moral I can see is that if I 'd acted like a blackguard — as ninety-nine men out of a hundred would have done — and let Jenny go to the dogs , I should have remained happy and contented and prosperous . And she , I dare say , would n't have died .... It 's because I tried to do my duty and act like a gentleman and a man of honour , that all this misery has come about .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Looking at him quietly .I think I should put it in another way . One has to be very strong and very sure of oneself to go against the ordinary view of things . And if one is n't , perhaps it 's better not to run any risks , but just to walk along the same secure old road as the common herd . It 's not exhilarating , it 's not brave , and it 's rather dull . But it 's eminently safe .

div.stage: BASIL scarcely hears the last words , but listens intently to other sounds outside .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: What 's that ? I thought I heard a carriage .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: A little surprised .Do you expect any one ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: I sent a wire to — to Hilda at the same time as to you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Already ?

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Excited .D'you think she 'll come ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: A ring is heard at the front door .I do n't know .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Running to the window .There 's some one at the door .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Perhaps it 's occurred to her also that you 're free .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: With the utmost passion .Oh , she loves me , and I — I adore her . God forgive me , I can n't help it .

div.stage: FANNY comes in .

sp.speaker: FANNY
sp.p: If you please , sir , the Coroner 's officer .

back.note: PRINTED BY BALLANTYNE & COMPANY LTD AT THE BALLANTYNE PRESS TAVISTOCK STREET COVENT GARDEN LONDON
